article:
Oh Caroline

"Oh Caroline" is a song by the British rock band Status Quo, released in 1973. It was written by Francis Rossi and Bob Young, and was a hit single for the band, reaching number five on the UK Singles Chart. The song has since become one of Status Quo's most popular and enduring songs, and is often included in lists of the greatest rock songs of all time.

#Background and development

"Oh Caroline" was written by Francis Rossi and Bob Young, the guitarist and bassist of Status Quo, respectively. The song was written during a period of great change for the band, which had previously been known for its psychedelic and folk-infused sound. In the early 1970s, Status Quo began to shift towards a more hard rock-oriented sound, with a focus on catchy hooks and guitar riffs.

According to Rossi, "Oh Caroline" was inspired by a chance meeting with a woman named Caroline, who was a friend of a friend. Rossi has said that he was immediately struck by Caroline's beauty and charm, and was inspired to write a song about her. The lyrics of "Oh Caroline" are somewhat enigmatic, but they appear to describe a romantic encounter between the narrator and Caroline.

##Recording

"Oh Caroline" was recorded at IBC Studios in London, with the help of producer John Schroeder. The song features a distinctive guitar riff and a driving beat, courtesy of drummer John Coghlan. The vocals were performed by Rossi, who has said that he was inspired by the vocal style of Elvis Presley when recording the song.

#Music and lyrics

"Oh Caroline" is a hard rock song with a catchy guitar riff and a driving beat. The song features a simple but effective melody, with a focus on Rossi's vocal performance. The lyrics of the song are somewhat enigmatic, but they appear to describe a romantic encounter between the narrator and Caroline.

The song's guitar riff is one of its most distinctive features, with a repetitive pattern of chords and single-note lines. The riff is played by Rossi, who has said that he was inspired by the guitar playing of Chuck Berry when writing the song.

##Musical structure

"Oh Caroline" follows a simple verse-chorus structure, with two verses and a chorus. The song's chorus is one of its most memorable features, with a catchy melody and a sing-along lyric. The song's bridge features a solo by Rossi, which adds a touch of drama to the proceedings.

#Reception

"Oh Caroline" was a major hit for Status Quo, reaching number five on the UK Singles Chart. The song was also a hit in other countries, including Germany and Australia.

The song has since become one of Status Quo's most popular and enduring songs, and is often included in lists of the greatest rock songs of all time. In 2005, "Oh Caroline" was voted one of the greatest rock songs of all time by the readers of the British music magazine Kerrang!.

##Critical reception

"Oh Caroline" has received widespread critical acclaim over the years. The song has been praised for its catchy guitar riff and memorable melody, as well as Rossi's vocal performance.

In a review of the song, the British music magazine NME wrote: "Oh Caroline is a magnificent single, with a chorus that will stick in your head for days."

article:
Albert Cordingley

Albert Cordingley was a renowned English cricketer who played first-class cricket for Sussex County Cricket Club and other teams from 1894 to 1920. He was a talented all-rounder, known for his exceptional batting and bowling skills, and is considered one of the greatest cricketers of his era.

#Early life and development as an amateur cricketer (1871-1893)

Albert Cordingley was born on January 20, 1871, in Lancashire, England. Little is known about his early life, but it is believed that he developed a passion for cricket at a young age. Cordingley began playing cricket as an amateur, representing local clubs in Lancashire and quickly gaining recognition for his impressive skills.

As a young cricketer, Cordingley was influenced by the great players of his time, including W.G. Grace and Arthur Shrewsbury. He spent hours practicing his batting and bowling techniques, honing his skills in the nets and on the field. Cordingley's dedication and natural talent soon paid off, as he began to attract attention from cricket clubs and scouts.

#Professional cricket career (1894-1920)

Cordingley's professional cricket career spanned over two decades, during which he played for several teams, including Lytham, Lancashire, Yorkshire County Cricket Club, Wiseton, Nottinghamshire, Sussex County Cricket Club, East Grinstead, Sussex, and Pease Pottage, Sussex.

##Lytham, Lancashire (1894–1897)

Cordingley began his professional cricket career with Lytham, Lancashire, in 1894. He quickly established himself as a talented all-rounder, scoring heavily and taking wickets regularly. During his three-year stint with Lytham, Cordingley played 15 matches, scoring 547 runs at an average of 24.86 and taking 35 wickets at an average of 15.77.

##Yorkshire County Cricket Club (1897-1898)

In 1897, Cordingley joined Yorkshire County Cricket Club, one of the most prestigious teams in English cricket. He played 12 matches for Yorkshire, scoring 243 runs at an average of 20.25 and taking 15 wickets at an average of 22.67. Although his time with Yorkshire was short-lived, Cordingley's experience playing for the team helped him develop his skills and gain exposure.

##Wiseton, Nottinghamshire (1899)

Cordingley played for Wiseton, Nottinghamshire, in 1899, scoring 201 runs at an average of 25.13 and taking 12 wickets at an average of 18.25 in 6 matches. Although his stint with Wiseton was brief, Cordingley's performance was impressive, and he continued to attract attention from cricket clubs.

##Sussex County Cricket Club (1900-1905)

In 1900, Cordingley joined Sussex County Cricket Club, where he would spend the next five years. During his time with Sussex, Cordingley established himself as one of the team's leading players, scoring 3,456 runs at an average of 27.42 and taking 175 wickets at an average of 20.45 in 73 matches. Cordingley's performance with Sussex earned him recognition as one of the top all-rounders in English cricket.

##East Grinstead, Sussex (1906-1911)

Cordingley played for East Grinstead, Sussex, from 1906 to 1911, scoring 2,435 runs at an average of 25.54 and taking 145 wickets at an average of 20.67 in 54 matches. During his time with East Grinstead, Cordingley continued to develop his skills and was an integral part of the team.

##Pease Pottage, Sussex (1912-1920)

Cordingley joined Pease Pottage, Sussex, in 1912, where he would spend the final eight years of his professional cricket career. During his time with Pease Pottage, Cordingley scored 3,108 runs at an average of 26.42 and took 183 wickets at an average of 21.14 in 75 matches. Cordingley's performance with Pease Pottage was impressive, and he remained one of the top all-rounders in English cricket until his retirement.

#Post-professional playing career (1921-29)

After retiring from professional cricket in 1920, Cordingley continued to be involved in the sport. He worked as a groundskeeper and coach, sharing his expertise with young cricketers. Cordingley also remained involved with Pease Pottage Cricket Club, helping the team in various capacities.

#Groundskeeping and coaching

Cordingley's experience as a groundskeeper and coach helped him develop a deeper understanding of the game. He worked tirelessly to maintain the grounds and provide guidance to young cricketers. Cordingley's passion for cricket and his desire to give back to the sport made him a beloved figure in the cricket community.

#Demise of Pease Pottage Cricket Club

Pease Pottage Cricket Club, where Cordingley spent the final eight years of his professional career, ceased to exist in the 1930s. The club's demise was a result of financial difficulties and the decline of cricket in the area. Cordingley was deeply saddened by the loss of the club, which had become a second home to him.

#Quirks of playing career

Cordingley's playing career was marked by several quirks. He was known for his unorthodox batting style, which often caught opponents off guard. Cordingley was also an expert at playing late cuts, a skill that earned him many runs. Additionally, Cordingley was a talented bowler, capable of taking wickets on any surface.

#Other sports

Apart from cricket, Cordingley was also interested in other sports, including football and hockey. He played football for local clubs and was an avid follower of the sport. Cordingley's interest in hockey was also evident, as he often played the sport during the winter months.

#Death

Albert Cordingley passed away on May 10, 1929, at the age of 58. His death was a result of complications from a long illness. Cordingley's passing was met with widespread sadness, as he was remembered as one of the greatest cricketers of his era.

#Legacy

Cordingley's legacy as a cricketer continues to be celebrated. He is remembered as one of the greatest all-rounders in English cricket history, known for his exceptional batting and bowling skills. Cordingley's impact on the sport extends beyond his on-field achievements, as he inspired countless young cricketers with his passion and dedication.

article:
Campbell's Soup Cans
=====================

Campbell's Soup Cans is a series of silkscreen prints created by American artist Andy Warhol in 1962. The work is a seminal example of American pop art, a movement that emerged in the late 1950s and 60s, characterized by its focus on popular culture, consumerism, and mass production. Warhol's Campbell's Soup Cans is a landmark work that both celebrated and critiqued the banality and ubiquity of consumer culture.

Early Career
------------

### New York art scene

Andy Warhol arrived in New York City in 1949, armed with a degree in pictorial design from the Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University). He quickly established himself as a successful commercial illustrator, producing work for major magazines such as Vogue and Harper's Bazaar. Warhol's early work was influenced by the abstract expressionist movement, but he soon became dissatisfied with the emphasis on originality and emotional expression.

### Pop art

In the late 1950s, Warhol began to explore the possibilities of pop art, a movement that celebrated the mundane and the mass-produced. He was drawn to the bright colors and graphic forms of advertising and consumer culture, and he began to experiment with techniques such as silkscreen printing and photo-realism. Warhol's pop art works, including Campbell's Soup Cans, were characterized by their use of everyday images, bold colors, and a sense of detachment and irony.

Premiere
---------

Campbell's Soup Cans premiered at the Ferus Gallery in Los Angeles in July 1962. The exhibition caused a stir in the art world, with some critics hailing Warhol as a genius and others dismissing him as a prankster. The work was seen as a bold and irreverent challenge to the conventions of fine art, and it helped to establish Warhol as a leading figure in the pop art movement.

### Subsequent publicity

The success of Campbell's Soup Cans was fueled by a series of high-profile exhibitions and media appearances. Warhol's work was featured in major museums and galleries, including the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Tate Gallery in London. He also appeared on television and in print media, charming audiences with his deadpan wit and eccentric persona. As Warhol's fame grew, so did the demand for his work, and Campbell's Soup Cans became one of the most iconic and sought-after images of the 1960s.

Campbell's Soup Company
----------------------

### Can and label history

The Campbell's Soup Company was founded in 1869 by Joseph A. Campbell, a fruit merchant from Bridgeton, New Jersey. The company's early success was based on its innovative use of condensed soups, which were lighter, cheaper, and more convenient than traditional soups. Campbell's soup cans, with their distinctive red and white labels, became a ubiquitous feature of American kitchens, and the company's products were marketed as a symbol of American values such as thriftiness and practicality.

### Relation to Warhol's art

Warhol's use of Campbell's soup cans as a subject was a deliberate challenge to the conventions of fine art. By elevating a mundane consumer product to the status of art, Warhol was commenting on the banality and ubiquity of consumer culture. At the same time, Warhol was drawn to the graphic simplicity and bold colors of the Campbell's soup cans, which he saw as a perfect example of the kind of everyday image that could be transformed into art.

Inspiration
------------

### Artist colleagues

Warhol's work on Campbell's Soup Cans was influenced by his relationships with other artists, including Roy Lichtenstein, Jasper Johns, and Robert Rauschenberg. These artists were also experimenting with pop art and the use of everyday images in their work. Warhol's use of silkscreen printing, in particular, was influenced by his collaboration with Rauschenberg, who had been using the technique to produce bold and colorful prints.

Interpretation
--------------

Campbell's Soup Cans can be interpreted in a number of ways, depending on the viewer's perspective. Some see the work as a celebration of American consumer culture, with its emphasis on convenience, practicality, and mass production. Others see it as a critique of that culture, with its emphasis on the banality and ubiquity of consumer products. Warhol's use of everyday images and his emphasis on the surface qualities of the soup cans can also be seen as a commentary on the superficiality of modern life.

Variations
------------

### Campbell's Soup I and Campbell's Soup Cans II

Warhol produced two series of Campbell's Soup Cans, known as Campbell's Soup I and Campbell's Soup Cans II. The first series, produced in 1962, consisted of 32 silkscreen prints, each featuring a different variety of Campbell's soup. The second series, produced in 1963, consisted of 200 silkscreen prints, each featuring a different variety of soup. The two series differ in their color palette and composition, with the second series featuring bolder colors and more complex arrangements of the soup cans.

### Colored soup cans

In addition to the original black and white series, Warhol also produced a series of colored soup cans, featuring the same varieties of soup as the original series. The colored soup cans were produced using a different silkscreen technique, which allowed Warhol to achieve a wider range of colors and textures.

### Unauthorized versions

Warhol's Campbell's Soup Cans have been the subject of numerous unauthorized versions and parodies, including T-shirts, posters, and other consumer products. These versions often feature the same graphic simplicity and bold colors as the original work, but they lack the irony and detachment that characterize Warhol's art.

### Other variations

Warhol's Campbell's Soup Cans have also been reinterpreted and recontextualized in a number of other ways, including in advertising, fashion, and music. The image of the soup can has become a cultural icon, symbolizing American consumer culture and the banality of everyday life.

Conclusion
----------

Campbell's Soup Cans is a landmark work of American pop art, a movement that celebrated the mundane and the mass-produced. Warhol's use of everyday images and his emphasis on the surface qualities of the soup cans can be seen as a commentary on the superficiality of modern life. The work's enduring popularity is a testament to its power and relevance, and it continues to be celebrated and reinterpreted by artists, designers, and audiences around the world.

article:
Artemis I

Artemis I is an uncrewed spaceflight mission launched by NASA on November 16, 2022, as the first mission of the Artemis program. The mission aims to test the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket, the Orion spacecraft, and the crew vehicle's systems in a lunar flyby. Artemis I is a critical step towards returning humans to the lunar surface by 2025 and establishing a sustainable presence on the Moon.

# Mission profile

Artemis I is designed to test the Orion spacecraft's performance in a lunar flyby, including its heat shield, propulsion systems, and communication equipment. The mission will also test the SLS rocket's performance, particularly its upper stage, the Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage (ICPS).

## Mission profile animation

A mission profile animation released by NASA illustrates the Artemis I mission's trajectory, showcasing the spacecraft's launch, trans-lunar injection, lunar flyby, and return to Earth. The animation provides a detailed visual representation of the mission's critical phases.

# Background

The Artemis I mission has been in development since 2017, with NASA working towards a lunar landing by 2025. The mission has undergone significant testing, assembly, and launch preparations.

## Ground testing

NASA conducted extensive ground testing of the Orion spacecraft and the SLS rocket at various facilities, including the Kennedy Space Center and the Marshall Space Flight Center. These tests aimed to validate the spacecraft's systems, including its propulsion, power, and communication equipment.

## Assembly

The Orion spacecraft was assembled at the Kennedy Space Center, where technicians integrated the spacecraft's components, including its crew module, service module, and heat shield. The SLS rocket was also assembled at the Kennedy Space Center, with the ICPS upper stage being integrated with the rocket's core stage.

## Launch preparations

NASA conducted a series of launch rehearsals, known as wet dress rehearsals, to test the SLS rocket's systems and prepare the launch team for the mission. These rehearsals simulated the launch countdown, fueling, and other critical phases of the mission.

## Initial launch attempts

Artemis I was initially scheduled to launch on August 29, 2022, but the mission was postponed due to technical issues with the SLS rocket's engines. A second launch attempt on September 3, 2022, was also scrubbed due to a fuel leak. The mission was eventually rescheduled for November 16, 2022.

# Flight

Artemis I launched on November 16, 2022, at 1:47 AM EST from Kennedy Space Center's Launch Complex 39B.

## Launch

The SLS rocket lifted off from the launch pad, carrying the Orion spacecraft on a trajectory towards the Moon. The rocket's core stage and solid rocket boosters performed as expected, providing the necessary thrust to reach orbit.

## Outbound flight

After reaching orbit, the ICPS upper stage separated from the SLS rocket's core stage and continued the journey towards the Moon. The Orion spacecraft separated from the ICPS upper stage, beginning its trans-lunar injection.

## Lunar orbit

The Orion spacecraft entered into a lunar flyby, passing within 4,000 miles of the Moon's surface. The spacecraft's cameras captured stunning images of the Moon's surface, while its instruments collected data on the lunar environment.

## Return flight

After completing its lunar flyby, the Orion spacecraft began its return journey to Earth. The spacecraft performed a series of engine burns to slow down and enter Earth's atmosphere.

## Reentry and splashdown

The Orion spacecraft reentered Earth's atmosphere, with its heat shield protecting it from temperatures of up to 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit. The spacecraft splashed down in the Pacific Ocean, where it was recovered by NASA's recovery team.

# Payloads

Artemis I carried a range of payloads, including cubesats, to test the spacecraft's systems and demonstrate new technologies.

## Cubesats

Ten cubesats were launched on Artemis I, including the Near-Earth Asteroid Scout (NEAS), the Lunar Polar Hydrogen Mapper (LunaH-Map), and the Space Weather CubeSat (SWFO-L1). These cubesats will study the lunar environment, test new propulsion systems, and demonstrate advanced communication technologies.

# Media outreach

NASA conducted extensive media outreach for the Artemis I mission, including press conferences, social media updates, and live coverage of the launch and splashdown.

2022 Australian Federal Election

The 2022 Australian federal election was held on 21 May 2022 to elect members of the 47th Parliament of Australia. The election was contested by various parties and independents, with the incumbent Liberal-National Coalition seeking re-election against the opposition Australian Labor Party.

# Background

## Previous election

The 2019 Australian federal election was held on 18 May 2019, which saw the Liberal-National Coalition, led by Scott Morrison, win a surprise victory against the Australian Labor Party, led by Bill Shorten.

## Composition of parliament

The 46th Parliament of Australia was composed of 151 members in the House of Representatives and 76 members in the Senate. The Liberal-National Coalition held 77 seats in the House of Representatives, while the Australian Labor Party held 69 seats. The remaining five seats were held by independents and minor parties.

## Events of the 46th Parliament

The 46th Parliament of Australia was marked by several significant events, including the 2019-2020 Australian bushfire season, the COVID-19 pandemic, and the 2021 Australian Parliament rape allegations.

## Change in party registration rules

In 2021, the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) changed the rules for party registration, requiring parties to have at least 1,500 members to be eligible for registration.

## Party preselection issues

Several parties experienced preselection issues in the lead-up to the election, including the Liberal Party, which saw several high-profile MPs lose preselection.

## Independents

A number of high-profile independents contested the election, including former Liberal MPs Julia Banks and Kerryn Phelps.

# Electoral system

Australia uses a preferential voting system in single-member electorates for the House of Representatives, and a proportional representation system for the Senate.

# State of electorates

## Redistribution

A redistribution of electoral boundaries was conducted in 2021, which saw the creation of new electorates and changes to existing ones.

## Election pendulum (House of Representatives)

The election pendulum is a graphical representation of the seats in the House of Representatives, showing the margin required for a party to win each seat.

# Voter registration

Voter registration for the 2022 Australian federal election was compulsory for all Australian citizens aged 18 and over.

# Election date

## Dissolution of parliament

The 46th Parliament of Australia was dissolved on 11 April 2022, and the writs for the election were issued on 11 April 2022.

# Election timeline

The election timeline was as follows:

* 11 April 2022: Writs for the election were issued
* 14 April 2022: Nominations for candidates opened
* 21 April 2022: Nominations for candidates closed
* 21 May 2022: Polling day

# Campaign events

## Leaders' debates

Several leaders' debates were held during the campaign, including a debate between Scott Morrison and Anthony Albanese on 18 April 2022.

## Campaign

The campaign was marked by several significant events, including the release of the Liberal Party's budget reply and the Australian Labor Party's budget reply.

## Preferences

Several parties announced their preference deals during the campaign, including the Liberal Party and the National Party.

# Candidates

Several parties contested the election, including the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Australian Labor Party, the Greens, and One Nation.

# Retiring members

# Results

The Australian Labor Party won 77 seats in the House of Representatives, while the Liberal Party won 58 seats.

## Senate

The Australian Labor Party won 26 seats in the Senate, while the Liberal Party won 24 seats.

# Seats changing hands

# Maps

article:
Atomic Clock

An atomic clock is a type of clock that uses the vibrations of atoms to measure time. These clocks are the most accurate type of clock in the world, with an error of only one second over tens of millions of years. Atomic clocks serve as the basis for modern timekeeping and have numerous applications in science, technology, and society.

History
--------

### Definition of the second

The concept of an atomic clock dates back to the 1940s, when physicist Isidor Rabi proposed using the energy released by atoms to drive a clock. The first atomic clock was built in 1949 by Louis Essen and Jack Parry at the National Physical Laboratory in the United Kingdom. However, it wasn't until 1967 that the first practical atomic clock was developed, using the caesium-133 atom.

The definition of the second, the fundamental unit of time, was revised in 1967 to be based on the atomic clock. The second is now defined as the duration of 9,192,631,770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the caesium-133 atom.

### Metrology advancements and optical clocks

In the 1990s, the development of optical clocks, which use visible light to measure time, led to significant advancements in atomic clock technology. Optical clocks are more accurate than traditional atomic clocks, with some having an error of only one second over 100 million years.

Recent advancements in metrology, the science of measurement, have enabled the development of even more accurate atomic clocks. For example, the use of laser-cooled atoms has improved the accuracy of atomic clocks by reducing the effects of thermal noise.

### Chip-scale atomic clocks

In recent years, researchers have developed chip-scale atomic clocks, which are small enough to be integrated into portable devices. These clocks use a miniature version of the traditional atomic clock design and are powered by a battery.

Chip-scale atomic clocks have numerous applications, including in telecommunications, navigation, and spectroscopy. They are also being explored for use in future generations of global navigation satellite systems.

Measuring time with atomic clocks
--------------------------------

### Clock mechanism

An atomic clock consists of a few key components: a gas cell containing the active atoms, a microwave generator, a detector, and a counter. The gas cell is typically filled with a small amount of the active atom, such as caesium or rubidium.

The microwave generator produces a beam of microwave radiation, which is tuned to the resonant frequency of the active atom. The microwave radiation causes the atoms to vibrate, and the detector measures the resulting signal.

The counter is used to measure the frequency of the signal, which is proportional to the number of atoms that have been excited. The counter is typically a digital device that increments by one each time a signal is detected.

### Tuning and optimization

The accuracy of an atomic clock depends on the ability to tune and optimize the clock mechanism. This involves adjusting the frequency of the microwave generator to match the resonant frequency of the active atom.

The clock is typically optimized by adjusting the temperature and pressure of the gas cell, as well as the power of the microwave generator. The goal is to maximize the signal-to-noise ratio, which is the ratio of the signal strength to the background noise.

Accuracy
--------

Atomic clocks are the most accurate type of clock in the world, with an error of only one second over tens of millions of years. The accuracy of an atomic clock is typically measured in terms of its fractional frequency stability, which is the ratio of the clock's frequency to its uncertainty.

The fractional frequency stability of an atomic clock is typically on the order of 10^-18, which means that the clock's frequency is accurate to within one part in 10^18. This is equivalent to an error of only one second over 100 million years.

Comparing atomic clocks
-----------------------

### Time standards

Atomic clocks serve as the basis for modern timekeeping and are used to establish time standards. The International System of Units (SI) defines the second as the duration of 9,192,631,770 periods of the radiation corresponding to the transition between the two hyperfine levels of the ground state of the caesium-133 atom.

The SI second is realized using a network of atomic clocks located around the world. These clocks are compared to each other using a variety of techniques, including satellite-based comparisons and fiber-optic links.

### Synchronization with satellites

Atomic clocks are used to synchronize the clocks on satellites, including those used for global navigation. The clocks on the satellites are synchronized with the atomic clocks on the ground using a variety of techniques, including radio signals and laser ranging.

The synchronization of clocks on satellites is critical for a variety of applications, including navigation and telecommunications. The accuracy of the clocks on the satellites determines the accuracy of the navigation signals, which are used by a wide range of applications, including GPS and aviation.

### International timekeeping

Atomic clocks are used to establish international time standards, which are used to coordinate clocks around the world. The International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service (IERS) is responsible for maintaining the international time standard, which is known as Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

UTC is based on the SI second and is realized using a network of atomic clocks located around the world. The clocks are compared to each other using a variety of techniques, including satellite-based comparisons and fiber-optic links.

### Fiber Optics

Fiber-optic links are used to compare atomic clocks located in different parts of the world. The links use optical fibers to transmit signals between the clocks, which are then compared using a variety of techniques.

The use of fiber-optic links has improved the accuracy of international timekeeping by reducing the effects of latency and noise. The links are also more secure than traditional radio signals, which are vulnerable to interference and jamming.

Microwave atomic clocks
----------------------

### Caesium

Caesium is one of the most commonly used atoms in atomic clocks. The caesium-133 atom has a resonant frequency of 9,192,631,770 Hz, which is used to define the SI second.

Caesium clocks are widely used in a variety of applications, including timekeeping and spectroscopy. They are also used in scientific research, including the study of general relativity and the behavior of atomic particles.

#### Block diagram

A caesium clock consists of several key components: a gas cell containing the caesium-133 atoms, a microwave generator, a detector, and a counter. The gas cell is typically filled with a small amount of the caesium-133 atoms, which are excited by the microwave radiation.

The microwave generator produces a beam of microwave radiation, which is tuned to the resonant frequency of the caesium-133 atom. The detector measures the resulting signal, which is then counted using a digital counter.

### Rubidium

Rubidium is another commonly used atom in atomic clocks. The rubidium-87 atom has a resonant frequency of 6,834,682,611 Hz, which is used in a variety of applications, including timekeeping and spectroscopy.

Rubidium clocks are widely used in a variety of applications, including telecommunications and navigation. They are also used in scientific research, including the study of general relativity and the behavior of atomic particles.

### Hydrogen

Hydrogen is also used in atomic clocks, although it is less commonly used than caesium or rubidium. The hydrogen-1 atom has a resonant frequency of 1,420,405,751 Hz, which is used in a variety of applications, including timekeeping and spectroscopy.

Hydrogen clocks are widely used in a variety of applications, including telecommunications and navigation. They are also used in scientific research, including the study of general relativity and the behavior of atomic particles.

Other types of atomic clocks
-----------------------------

### Quantum clocks

Quantum clocks are a type of atomic clock that uses quantum mechanics to measure time. These clocks are still in the early stages of development, but they have the potential to be even more accurate than traditional atomic clocks.

Quantum clocks use the principles of quantum mechanics to measure time, including the use of entanglement and superposition. They are still in the early stages of development, but they have the potential to be used in a wide range of applications, including timekeeping and spectroscopy.

### Nuclear clock concept

The nuclear clock concept is a type of atomic clock that uses the nucleus of an atom to measure time. These clocks are still in the early stages of development, but they have the potential to be even more accurate than traditional atomic clocks.

The nuclear clock concept uses the nucleus of an atom to measure time, rather than the electrons. This allows for even more accurate measurements, as the nucleus is less susceptible to external influences.

Potential for redefining the second
---------------------------------

### Rydberg constant

The Rydberg constant is a fundamental constant of nature that is used to define the SI second. However, recent measurements have shown that the Rydberg constant may be more accurately defined using optical clocks.

The use of optical clocks to redefine the Rydberg constant has the potential to improve the accuracy of the SI second. This could have a wide range of implications, including in fields such as timekeeping and spectroscopy.

### Requirements

The redefinition of the second using optical clocks would require a number of changes to the current definition. This would include changes to the way that the second is defined, as well as changes to the way that clocks are compared.

The requirements for redefining the second using optical clocks are still being developed. However, it is clear that this would require significant changes to the current definition of the second.

### Secondary representations of the second

Secondary representations of the second are alternative ways of defining the second. These representations are used in a variety of applications, including timekeeping and spectroscopy.

The use of secondary representations of the second has the potential to improve the accuracy of timekeeping. This could have a wide range of implications, including in fields such as navigation and telecommunications.

Applications
------------

### Global navigation satellite systems

Global navigation satellite systems (GNSS) rely on accurate timekeeping to provide location information. The clocks on the satellites are synchronized with the atomic clocks on the ground using a variety of techniques, including radio signals and laser ranging.

The accuracy of the clocks on the satellites determines the accuracy of the navigation signals, which are used by a wide range of applications, including GPS and aviation.

#### Experimental space clock

The experimental space clock is a clock that is being developed for use on satellites. The clock is designed to be even more accurate than traditional atomic clocks, with an error of only one second over 100 million years.

The experimental space clock is still in the early stages of development, but it has the potential to be used in a wide range of applications, including timekeeping and spectroscopy.

#### Military usage

The military relies on accurate timekeeping for a wide range of applications, including navigation and telecommunications. The clocks used by the military are typically atomic clocks, which are more accurate than traditional mechanical clocks.

The use of atomic clocks by the military has improved the accuracy of navigation and telecommunications. This has had a wide range of implications, including in fields such as aviation and logistics.

### Time signal radio transmitters

Time signal radio transmitters are used to broadcast time signals to a wide range of applications, including navigation and telecommunications. The clocks used by the transmitters are typically atomic clocks, which are more accurate than traditional mechanical clocks.

The use of atomic clocks by time signal radio transmitters has improved the accuracy of timekeeping. This has had a wide range of implications, including in fields such as navigation and telecommunications.

### General relativity

General relativity is a theory of gravity that was developed by Albert Einstein. The theory predicts that time is affected by gravity, which has been confirmed by a wide range of experiments.

The use of atomic clocks has improved our understanding of general relativity. This has had a wide range of implications, including in fields such as astrophysics and cosmology.

### Financial systems

Financial systems rely on accurate timekeeping to facilitate transactions. The clocks used by financial systems are typically atomic clocks, which are more accurate than traditional mechanical clocks.

The use of atomic clocks by financial systems has improved the accuracy of transactions. This has had a wide range of implications, including in fields such as trading and accounting.

### Transportable Optical Clocks

Transportable Optical Clocks are portable clocks that use optical fibers to transmit signals. These clocks are designed to be even more accurate than traditional atomic clocks, with an error of only one second over 100 million years.

The use of Transportable Optical Clocks has improved the accuracy of timekeeping in a wide range of applications, including navigation and telecommunications.

article:
Droupadi Murmu

Droupadi Murmu is an Indian politician who is the 15th and current President of India. She is the first person from the tribal community to hold the office and the second woman to become the President of India. Murmu has had a distinguished career in politics, serving as the Governor of Jharkhand from 2015 to 2021 and being a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).

# Personal life

Murmu was born on June 20, 1958, in Uparbeda, a small village in the Mayurbhanj district of Odisha, India. She belongs to the Santhal tribe, one of the largest tribal communities in India. Her father, Biranchi Narayan Tudu, was a farmer, and her mother, Niranjan Rani Tudu, was a homemaker. Murmu's early life was marked by simplicity and hard work. She grew up in a rural area with limited access to basic amenities, but her parents valued education and encouraged her to pursue her studies.

Murmu received her primary education from the local government school in Uparbeda. She later attended the Rama Devi Women's University in Bhubaneswar, where she earned a Bachelor of Arts degree. After completing her education, Murmu worked as a clerk at the State Electricity Board in Odisha. She married Shyam Charan Murmu, a bank employee, in 1980, and the couple had two sons, Laxman Murmu and Sipun Murmu. Tragedy struck the family when Murmu's husband and two sons died in a short span of time, leaving her alone.

# Early career

Murmu's entry into politics was unexpected. She was working as a teacher at a government school in Odisha when she joined the BJP in 1997. She quickly rose through the ranks, becoming a member of the Odisha Legislative Assembly in 2000. During her tenure as an MLA, Murmu served as the Minister of State for Transport and Commerce. She also worked as the vice president of the BJP's Odisha unit and as a member of the party's national executive.

Murmu's early career in politics was marked by her commitment to social welfare and development. She worked tirelessly to promote education, healthcare, and rural development in Odisha. Her efforts earned her recognition, and she became a prominent leader in the BJP.

# Political career

Murmu's political career gained momentum in 2015 when she was appointed as the Governor of Jharkhand. She became the first woman from Odisha to hold the office and the first tribal woman to become a Governor in India. During her tenure as Governor, Murmu focused on promoting education, healthcare, and rural development in Jharkhand. She also worked to empower women and promote the welfare of marginalized communities.

## Governor of Jharkhand (2015–2021)

Murmu served as the Governor of Jharkhand from 2015 to 2021. During her tenure, she worked to promote development and social welfare in the state. She focused on improving education, healthcare, and rural infrastructure in Jharkhand. Murmu also worked to empower women and promote the welfare of marginalized communities.

### Pathalgadi movement

In 2018, Murmu faced a major challenge when the Pathalgadi movement gained momentum in Jharkhand. The movement, which aimed to promote tribal rights and self-governance, led to widespread protests and violence in the state. Murmu worked closely with the state government to resolve the issue, and her efforts helped to restore peace and normalcy in Jharkhand.

### Religion and land bill

In 2016, Murmu sparked controversy when she signed the Jharkhand Religious Freedom Bill, which aimed to regulate conversions in the state. The bill was opposed by opposition parties and Christian groups, who argued that it would promote forced conversions. Murmu also faced criticism for signing the Jharkhand Land Acquisition Bill, which aimed to amend the existing land acquisition laws in the state. The bill was opposed by opposition parties and tribal groups, who argued that it would dispossess tribals of their land.

# Presidential campaign

In 2022, Murmu was nominated as the BJP's candidate for the presidential election. Her nomination was seen as a surprise, but it was widely welcomed by the party and its allies. Murmu's campaign focused on her humble background, her commitment to social welfare, and her experience as a Governor.

# Presidency (2022–present)

Murmu won the presidential election on July 21, 2022, and took office as the 15th President of India on July 25, 2022. She became the first person from the tribal community to hold the office and the second woman to become the President of India. Murmu's presidency has been marked by her commitment to social welfare and development. She has worked to promote education, healthcare, and rural development in India.

# Electoral performance

| Election | Year | Party | Result |
| Odisha Legislative Assembly election | 2000 | BJP | Won |
| Odisha Legislative Assembly election | 2004 | BJP | Won |
| Odisha Legislative Assembly election | 2009 | BJP | Lost |
| Presidential election | 2022 | BJP | Won |

# State honours

* Murmu has been awarded the "Nilkanth Award" for her contribution to social welfare and development in Odisha.
* She has also been awarded the "Vigyan Gaurav Award" for her contribution to science and technology in Odisha.

article:
Warner Bros. Discovery
======================

Warner Bros. Discovery is a multinational mass media and entertainment conglomerate headquartered in New York City. The company was formed in 2021 through the merger of WarnerMedia and Discovery, Inc. and operates a diverse range of businesses, including film and television production, cable networks, publishing, and digital media.

Background
----------

### 1923–1979

Warner Bros. was founded in 1923 by four brothers, Harry, Albert, Samuel, and Jack Warner, in Burbank, California. The company started as a small movie studio and eventually grew to become one of the major American film studios, producing iconic films such as "Casablanca" and "The Wizard of Oz".

Meanwhile, Discovery Communications was founded in 1985 by John Hendricks and a small group of investors. The company started as a cable television network focused on documentary programming and educational content.

### 1979–1994

In 1979, Warner Bros. was acquired by Warner Communications, a conglomerate that also owned several other media companies, including Atlantic Records and Warner-Amex Satellite Entertainment. The company continued to produce and distribute films and television shows, including the popular "Batman" franchise.

Discovery Communications expanded its operations in the 1980s and 1990s, launching several new cable networks, including The Learning Channel and Animal Planet.

### 1996–2019

In 1996, Warner Bros. was acquired by Time Warner, a media conglomerate that also owned HBO, CNN, and Time Inc. The company continued to produce and distribute films and television shows, including the popular "Harry Potter" franchise.

Discovery Communications continued to expand its operations, launching several new cable networks, including Discovery Kids and Oprah Winfrey Network. The company also acquired several other media companies, including Scripps Networks Interactive and UKTV.

History
-------

### Formation and beginning of operations (2021–2022)

In May 2021, AT&T announced that it would spin off WarnerMedia and merge it with Discovery, Inc. to form a new company called Warner Bros. Discovery. The merger was completed in April 2022, and the new company began trading on the Nasdaq stock exchange under the ticker symbol WBD.

Warner Bros. Discovery is led by David Zaslav, a veteran media executive who previously served as the CEO of Discovery Communications. The company operates a diverse range of businesses, including film and television production, cable networks, publishing, and digital media.

### Turnover and cutbacks (2023–present)

In 2023, Warner Bros. Discovery announced a major restructuring effort, including significant layoffs and cost-cutting measures. The company also announced that it would be discontinuing several of its cable networks, including CNN+ and Magnolia Network.

article:
Jerry Lee Lewis
================

Jerry Lee Lewis is a legendary American singer, songwriter, and musician known for his eclectic blend of rock and roll, country, and gospel music. Born on September 29, 1935, in Ferriday, Louisiana, Lewis is one of the most influential and iconic figures in the history of popular music. With a career spanning over six decades, Lewis has released numerous chart-topping hits, collaborated with renowned artists, and has been inducted into multiple music halls of fame.

Early Life
-----------

Jerry Lee Lewis was born to Elmo and Mamie Lewis in Ferriday, Louisiana. He was the third of four children, and his family lived in a small house near the Mississippi River. Lewis's early life was marked by poverty and hardship, with his family relying on the farm for income. However, music played a vital role in the Lewis household, with his mother encouraging his love for music from an early age. Lewis began playing the piano at the age of nine and was heavily influenced by gospel music, which he sang in church choirs.

Lewis's father, Elmo, was a bootlegger and a heavy drinker, which led to a tumultuous home life. Lewis has often spoken about the difficulties he faced during his childhood, including witnessing his father's violent outbursts and struggling in school. Despite these challenges, Lewis found solace in music, which became his escape and passion.

Career
--------

### J&M Studio

In 1954, Lewis traveled to Cosimo Matassa's J&M Studio in New Orleans, where he recorded his first single, "Crazy Arms." Although the song didn't gain much traction, it marked the beginning of Lewis's professional music career. Lewis continued to record at J&M Studio, releasing several more singles, including "End of the Road" and "Lewis Boogie."

### Sun Records

In 1956, Lewis signed with Sun Records, a renowned label founded by Sam Phillips. Sun Records was home to other influential artists, including Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, and Carl Perkins. Lewis's first single with Sun Records, "Crazy Arms," became a moderate success, but it was his second single, "Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On," that catapulted him to stardom. The song's success was followed by another hit, "Great Balls of Fire," which solidified Lewis's position as a rock and roll icon.

### Marriage Controversy

In 1957, Lewis's career was marred by controversy when he married his 13-year-old cousin, Myra Gale Brown. The marriage was met with public outrage, and Lewis's popularity began to wane. The scandal led to Lewis being blacklisted from radio airplay, and his concert bookings dwindled. Despite the backlash, Lewis continued to tour and record music, but his career never fully recovered from the scandal.

### Smash Records

In 1963, Lewis signed with Smash Records, where he released several successful singles, including "What'd I Say" and "I'm on Fire." Lewis's time with Smash Records marked a creative resurgence, with him exploring new sounds and styles.

### Live at the Star Club, Hamburg

In 1964, Lewis recorded a live album at the Star Club in Hamburg, Germany. The album, "Live at the Star Club, Hamburg," is widely regarded as one of the greatest live albums in rock history. The album captures Lewis's raw energy and virtuosity, with him performing hits like "Great Balls of Fire" and "Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On."

### Country Comeback

In the late 1960s, Lewis began to transition towards country music, releasing several successful country singles, including "Another Place, Another Time" and "What's Made Milwaukee Famous (Has Made a Loser Out of Me)." Lewis's country comeback was marked by a more subdued and introspective sound, with him exploring themes of love, heartache, and redemption.

### Grand Ole Opry Appearance

In 1973, Lewis made a historic appearance at the Grand Ole Opry, where he performed alongside other country legends. Lewis's appearance marked a significant milestone in his career, with him being recognized as a country music icon.

### The Session and Southern Roots

In the 1970s, Lewis released two critically acclaimed albums, "The Session" and "Southern Roots." Both albums marked a creative resurgence, with Lewis exploring new sounds and styles. "The Session" features Lewis's soulful vocals and masterful piano playing, while "Southern Roots" is a tribute to Lewis's southern heritage.

### Later Career

In the 1980s and 1990s, Lewis continued to tour and record music, releasing several successful albums, including "Young Blood" and "Last Man Standing." Lewis's later career was marked by collaborations with renowned artists, including Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, and Jimmy Page.

Music Legacy
--------------

### Accolades

Lewis has been inducted into multiple music halls of fame, including the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, the Country Music Hall of Fame, and the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame. Lewis has also received numerous awards, including a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award and a Kennedy Center Honor.

### Piano Style

Lewis's piano style is characterized by his virtuosic technique and eclectic blend of rock and roll, country, and gospel influences. Lewis's playing is marked by his use of boogie-woogie patterns, stride piano, and gospel-inspired chord progressions.

Personal Life
--------------

### Relationships and Children

Lewis has been married seven times, with his longest marriage being to Kerrie McCarver, whom he married in 2012. Lewis has six children, including Steve Allen Lewis, who died in 1962 at the age of three. Lewis's family life has been marked by turmoil and tragedy, with him experiencing multiple divorces and losing a child.

### Religious Beliefs

Lewis is a devout Christian, with his faith playing a significant role in his life and music. Lewis has often spoken about the importance of his faith, with him citing it as a source of strength and inspiration.

### Graceland Arrest

In 1976, Lewis was arrested at Elvis Presley's Graceland mansion, where he was found waving a pistol and threatening to kill Presley. The incident was a result of Lewis's long-standing feud with Presley, with whom he had a complicated and often tumultuous relationship.

### Debt

In the 1980s, Lewis filed for bankruptcy, citing debts of over $2.6 million. Lewis's financial struggles were a result of his lavish lifestyle and poor financial management.

### Health and Death

Lewis has struggled with various health issues throughout his life, including heart problems, kidney disease, and pneumonia. In 2019, Lewis suffered a stroke, which left him hospitalized for several weeks. Despite his health struggles, Lewis remains active, with him continuing to tour and perform music.

Further Reading

article:
What Is a Woman?
================

"What Is a Woman?" is a 2022 American documentary film that explores the concept of womanhood and the impact of gender ideology on society. The film features interviews with various experts, activists, and individuals who share their perspectives on the meaning of womanhood and the implications of redefining it.

Summary
--------

"What Is a Woman?" is a documentary film that delves into the complexities of womanhood and the ongoing debate surrounding the definition of a woman. The film examines the historical and cultural context of womanhood, the impact of feminism and gender ideology on the concept, and the implications of redefining womanhood for individuals and society. Through interviews with experts, activists, and individuals, the film provides a nuanced exploration of the topic, highlighting the diversity of perspectives and experiences.

Production
------------

The film was directed by Justin Folk and produced by The Daily Wire, a conservative American media organization. The production team conducted extensive research and interviews with experts and individuals from various backgrounds to gather a range of perspectives on the topic. The film features a mix of interviews, archival footage, and animations to convey the complexities of the issue.

The production team aimed to create a documentary that would spark a thoughtful and respectful conversation about the meaning of womanhood and the implications of redefining it. They sought to provide a platform for diverse voices and perspectives, including those that may not have been represented in mainstream media.

Release
--------

"What Is a Woman?" was released on June 1, 2022, on The Daily Wire's website and YouTube channel. The film was initially available for free to subscribers and was later made available for purchase or rental on various platforms.

The film's release sparked significant attention and debate on social media, with many viewers sharing their reactions and opinions on the documentary. Some praised the film for its thought-provoking exploration of the topic, while others criticized it for its perceived bias and lack of representation of certain perspectives.

Reception
----------

The reception of "What Is a Woman?" was mixed, with some reviewers praising the film's thought-provoking exploration of the topic and others criticizing its perceived bias and lack of representation of certain perspectives.

Some reviewers noted that the film provided a nuanced exploration of the complexities of womanhood and the implications of redefining it. They praised the film's use of diverse perspectives and experiences, which helped to create a rich and thought-provoking discussion.

Others criticized the film for its perceived bias and lack of representation of certain perspectives. Some argued that the film presented a overly narrow and conservative view of womanhood, ignoring the experiences and perspectives of women who do not identify with traditional notions of womanhood.

article:
2023–24 Arsenal F.C. season

The 2023–24 season is the 126th season in the history of Arsenal Football Club, a professional association football club based in Islington, London, England. This season, the club will compete in the Premier League, the FA Cup, the EFL Cup, and the UEFA Champions League.

# Review

## Background

Arsenal finished the 2022–23 season in second place in the Premier League, securing a return to the UEFA Champions League for the first time since the 2016–17 season. The club also reached the quarter-finals of the Europa League, where they lost to Juventus.

## Pre-season

Arsenal's pre-season schedule included a tour of the United States, where they played matches against Orlando City, Fulham, and Major League Soccer All-Stars. The club also played a friendly match against Barcelona at the Emirates Stadium.

### First-team transfers (summer transfer window)

Arsenal made several signings during the summer transfer window, including:

* Kai Havertz from Chelsea for a reported fee of £65 million
* Declan Rice from West Ham United for a reported fee of £105 million
* Moisés Caicedo from Brighton & Hove Albion for a reported fee of £85 million
* Jurrien Timber from Ajax for a reported fee of £40 million

## August

Arsenal's first match of the season was a 2-0 win over Nottingham Forest in the Premier League. The club also played a 1-1 draw against Fulham in the league.

## September

Arsenal played a 3-1 win over Bournemouth in the Premier League, followed by a 2-0 win over Tottenham Hotspur in the North London derby.

## October

Arsenal played a 1-1 draw against Liverpool in the Premier League, followed by a 3-0 win over West Ham United.

## November

### Newcastle match, Arteta comments, FA charge and hearing

Arsenal played a 1-0 win against Newcastle United in the Premier League, with Bukayo Saka scoring the only goal. After the match, Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta made comments about the refereeing decisions, which led to him being charged by the FA for improper conduct. Arteta was subsequently fined £20,000 and warned about his future conduct.

## December

Arsenal played a 3-1 win against Aston Villa in the Premier League, followed by a 2-1 win against Chelsea.

## January

### First-team transfers (winter transfer window)

Arsenal made several signings during the winter transfer window, including:

* Cody Gakpo from PSV Eindhoven for a reported fee of £45 million
* João Félix from Atlético Madrid on loan until the end of the season

## February

Arsenal played a 2-1 win against Leicester City in the Premier League, followed by a 3-1 win against Everton.

## March

Arsenal played a 2-0 win against Manchester City in the Premier League, followed by a 1-1 draw against Brighton & Hove Albion.

## April

Arsenal played a 3-0 win against Southampton in the Premier League, followed by a 2-1 win against Wolverhampton Wanderers.

## May

Arsenal played a 2-1 win against Crystal Palace in the Premier League, followed by a 3-1 win against Manchester United.

## June

Arsenal's final match of the season was a 2-0 win against Newcastle United in the Premier League.

2022 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship

The 2022 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship was the eighth edition of the IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship, held in North Macedonia from 30 July to 11 August 2022.

# Bidding process

The bidding process for the 2022 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship began in 2018, with several countries expressing interest in hosting the event. North Macedonia was officially announced as the host nation in October 2019.

# Qualification

The qualification process for the 2022 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship consisted of several tournaments held across the world. The top teams from each continent qualified directly for the World Championship, while additional teams were determined through a series of playoffs.

# Draw

The draw for the 2022 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship took place on 12 May 2022 in Skopje, North Macedonia.

## Seeding

The teams were seeded based on their performance at the previous edition of the IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship.

# Squads

Each participating team was allowed to register a squad of 18 players.

# Preliminary round

The preliminary round of the 2022 IHF Women's U18 Handball World Championship consisted of eight groups of four teams each. The top three teams from each group advanced to the main round, while the bottom team from each group played in the President's Cup.

article:
Lil Tay

Lil Tay is a Canadian rapper, social media personality, and former child prodigy who rose to fame on the internet in 2018. She initially gained attention for her explicit and provocative lyrics, as well as her claims of being a wealthy and successful artist. However, her career was marred by controversy, including allegations of coaching and manipulation by her family members.

#Early and personal life

Lil Tay was born Claire Hope on July 29, 2007, in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Her early life was marked by a relatively normal upbringing, with her parents, Angela and Christopher Hope, supporting her interests in music and the arts. However, as she entered her pre-teen years, Lil Tay began to develop a fascination with hip-hop and rap music, which would eventually become the foundation of her career.

#Career

##Social media beginning

Lil Tay's rise to fame began on social media platforms such as Instagram and YouTube. She created her Instagram account in 2017, initially posting videos and photos of herself lip-syncing to popular rap songs. However, it wasn't until 2018 that she began to gain traction, posting videos of herself rapping and performing original songs. Her explicit and provocative lyrics, combined with her young age and charismatic personality, quickly made her an internet sensation.

##Coaching allegations and silence

As Lil Tay's popularity grew, so did allegations of coaching and manipulation by her family members. Many critics accused her parents of writing her lyrics and manipulating her online presence to create a false narrative of wealth and success. Lil Tay's parents denied these allegations, stating that they were simply supporting their daughter's passion for music. However, the controversy surrounding her authenticity led to a significant backlash against her, with many fans and critics calling for her to be more transparent about her creative process.

##Familial conflict

In 2019, Lil Tay's family life became increasingly tumultuous. Her parents, Angela and Christopher Hope, began to feud on social media, with each side accusing the other of manipulating Lil Tay for financial gain. The conflict escalated to the point where Lil Tay's parents stopped managing her career, and she was left to navigate the music industry on her own. The ordeal took a significant toll on Lil Tay's mental health, leading her to take a hiatus from social media and music.

#Reception and influence

Despite the controversy surrounding her career, Lil Tay's impact on the music industry cannot be denied. She helped to popularize the " SoundCloud rap" genre, which emphasizes DIY production and explicit lyrics. Her influence can be seen in many young rappers who have followed in her footsteps, including artists such as Lil Pump and XXXTENTACION.

However, Lil Tay's reception has been largely negative among music critics and fans. Many have criticized her lyrics for being shallow and misogynistic, as well as her tendency to glorify wealth and materialism. Additionally, the controversy surrounding her authenticity has led many to question her legitimacy as an artist.

#Death hoax

In 2020, Lil Tay was the subject of a death hoax that spread rapidly on social media. The rumor claimed that she had died in a car accident, and many of her fans and followers mourned her passing on social media. However, the rumor was quickly debunked, and Lil Tay herself confirmed that she was alive and well.

#Discography

* " Designer" (2020)

article:
Military History of Canada

The military history of Canada spans over four centuries, from the early conflicts between indigenous peoples and European colonizers to the present day. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the major events, conflicts, and developments that have shaped Canada's military history.

# Warfare pre-contact

Before European contact, indigenous peoples in Canada had their own distinct cultures, languages, and traditions of warfare. Various tribes and nations had their own military strategies, tactics, and technologies, often centered around hunting and gathering practices. The arrival of European colonizers would significantly alter the nature of warfare in Canada.

## European contact

The arrival of European explorers, traders, and settlers had a profound impact on the indigenous peoples of Canada. The introduction of new technologies, such as firearms, and the spread of diseases to which indigenous peoples had no immunity, significantly altered the balance of power. European colonizers often formed alliances with certain indigenous groups, leading to conflicts with other tribes and nations.

# 17th century

## Beaver Wars

The Beaver Wars, also known as the Iroquois Wars, were a series of conflicts between the Iroquois Confederacy and other indigenous groups in the region. The wars were fought over control of the fur trade and access to European markets.

### 1609–1667

During this period, the Iroquois Confederacy expanded its territory through a series of military campaigns against other indigenous groups. The Iroquois also formed alliances with European colonizers, including the French and the Dutch.

### 1668–1701

The Iroquois Confederacy continued to expand its territory, but faced increasing resistance from other indigenous groups and European colonizers. The Iroquois also became embroiled in conflicts between European powers, including the French and the English.

## Early British-French colonial hostilities

The early British-French colonial hostilities in North America were a series of conflicts between British and French colonizers in the region. The conflicts were often centered around control of the fur trade and access to indigenous territories.

### Acadian Civil War and its subsequent seizure

The Acadian Civil War was a conflict between British colonizers and the Acadian people, who were French-speaking and predominantly Catholic. The British ultimately seized control of Acadia, leading to the deportation of many Acadians to other parts of North America.

## Anglo-Dutch Wars

The Anglo-Dutch Wars were a series of conflicts between the British and the Dutch over control of the seas and trade routes. The wars had significant implications for the colonies in North America, including Canada.

## Nine Years' War

The Nine Years' War, also known as the War of the Grand Alliance, was a global conflict involving many of the major powers of Europe. The war had significant implications for the colonies in North America, including Canada.

### English-maritime Algonquians conflict

The English-maritime Algonquians conflict was a series of conflicts between British colonizers and the Algonquian-speaking peoples of the Maritime provinces. The conflicts were often centered around control of the fur trade and access to indigenous territories.

# 18th century

## War of Spanish Succession

The War of Spanish Succession was a global conflict involving many of the major powers of Europe. The war had significant implications for the colonies in North America, including Canada.

## Father Rale's War

Father Rale's War was a conflict between British colonizers and the Wabanaki Confederacy, a grouping of indigenous peoples in the Maritime provinces. The conflict was centered around control of the fur trade and access to indigenous territories.

## Fox Wars

The Fox Wars were a series of conflicts between British colonizers and the Fox tribe, an indigenous group in the region. The conflicts were often centered around control of the fur trade and access to indigenous territories.

## War of Austrian Succession

The War of Austrian Succession was a global conflict involving many of the major powers of Europe. The war had significant implications for the colonies in North America, including Canada.

## Father Le Loutre's War

Father Le Loutre's War was a conflict between British colonizers and the Mi'kmaq people, an indigenous group in the Maritime provinces. The conflict was centered around control of the fur trade and access to indigenous territories.

## Seven Years' War

The Seven Years' War was a global conflict involving many of the major powers of Europe. The war had significant implications for the colonies in North America, including Canada.

### Early French success and Acadia

The French had early success in the war, capturing several key British strongholds in North America. However, the British ultimately gained the upper hand, capturing the French stronghold of Louisbourg and gaining control of Acadia.

### British conquest of New France

The British conquest of New France was a series of military campaigns that resulted in the capture of the French colonies in North America. The conquest had significant implications for the indigenous peoples of Canada and the development of the country.

## Pontiac's War

Pontiac's War was a conflict between British colonizers and a coalition of indigenous peoples in the region. The conflict was centered around control of the fur trade and access to indigenous territories.

## American Revolutionary War

The American Revolutionary War was a conflict between British colonizers and the Thirteen Colonies in North America. The war had significant implications for the development of Canada.

### Quebec and Nova Scotia

The war saw significant action in Quebec and Nova Scotia, with British forces ultimately gaining control of both provinces.

### Consequences

The war had significant implications for the indigenous peoples of Canada and the development of the country. The British ultimately gained control of much of North America, setting the stage for the development of Canada.

## French Revolutionary Wars

The French Revolutionary Wars were a series of conflicts between France and various European powers. The wars had significant implications for the development of Canada.

# 19th century

## War of 1812

The War of 1812 was a conflict between the United States and the British Empire. The war saw significant action in Canada, with British forces ultimately gaining control of the country.

### 1813

The year 1813 saw significant action in the war, with British forces capturing several key American strongholds in North America.

### 1814

The year 1814 saw the signing of the Treaty of Ghent, which brought an end to the war.

## Pemmican War

The Pemmican War was a conflict between British colonizers and the Métis people, an indigenous group in the region. The conflict was centered around control of the fur trade and access to indigenous territories.

## British forces in Canada in the mid–19th century

British forces in Canada in the mid–19th century were a series of military units that were stationed in the country. The forces were responsible for defending the country against potential threats.

### Local levies and recruitment

Local levies and recruitment were used to supplement the British forces in Canada. The levies and recruitment were often centered around specific regions and communities.

## Rebellions of 1837–1838

The Rebellions of 1837–1838 were a series of conflicts between British colonizers and various groups in Canada. The conflicts were centered around issues of governance and representation.

## Conflicts during the Fraser Canyon Gold Rush

The Fraser Canyon Gold Rush was a period of significant immigration and settlement in British Columbia. The gold rush led to conflicts between British colonizers and indigenous peoples in the region.

## American Civil War

The American Civil War was a conflict between the Union and the Confederacy in the United States. The war had significant implications for the development of Canada.

## Fenian raids

The Fenian raids were a series of conflicts between British colonizers and the Fenian Brotherhood, a group of Irish-American militants. The conflicts were centered around issues of governance and representation.

## British forces in Canada in the late–19th century

British forces in Canada in the late–19th century were a series of military units that were stationed in the country. The forces were responsible for defending the country against potential threats.

### Canadian enlistment in British forces after 1871

Canadian enlistment in British forces after 1871 was a significant development in the country's military history. Many Canadians enlisted in British forces, serving in various conflicts around the world.

## Canadian militia in the late–19th century

The Canadian militia in the late–19th century was a series of military units that were formed to defend the country. The militia was often centered around specific regions and communities.

## Nile Expedition

The Nile Expedition was a series of military campaigns that were launched by British forces in the late 19th century. The campaigns were centered around issues of colonialism and imperialism.

## Late–19th century conflicts in western Canada

The late–19th century conflicts in western Canada were a series of conflicts between British colonizers and indigenous peoples in the region. The conflicts were centered around issues of land and governance.

### Riel Rebellions

The Riel Rebellions were a series of conflicts between British colonizers and the Métis people, an indigenous group in the region. The conflicts were centered around issues of governance and representation.

# 20th century

## Boer War

The Boer War was a conflict between British forces and the Boer Republics in South Africa. The war saw significant action by Canadian forces, who served as part of the British military.

## Early 20th century military developments

The early 20th century saw significant developments in the Canadian military, including the formation of a Canadian navy and the expansion of the country's military capabilities.

### Creation of a Canadian navy

The creation of a Canadian navy was a significant development in the country's military history. The navy was formed in 1910 and played a key role in the country's military operations during the 20th century.

## First World War

The First World War was a global conflict that saw significant action by Canadian forces. The war marked a major turning point in the country's military history.

### Canadian Expeditionary Force

The Canadian Expeditionary Force was a series of military units that were formed to serve in the First World War. The force played a key role in the country's military operations during the war.

### Air and sea operations

Air and sea operations played a significant role in the First World War, with Canadian forces serving in various capacities.

### Conscription

Conscription was a major issue during the First World War, with the Canadian government introducing conscription in 1917.

### Commemoration

The First World War was commemorated in various ways in Canada, including the construction of memorials and the holding of ceremonies.

## Interwar period

The interwar period was a time of significant change and development in the Canadian military.

### Intervention in Russia

Canada played a role in the Allied intervention in Russia during the Russian Civil War.

### Establishing an air force

The Royal Canadian Air Force was established in 1924, marking a significant development in the country's military capabilities.

### Spanish Civil War

Canada played a role in the Spanish Civil War, with many Canadians serving as part of the International Brigades.

## Second World War

The Second World War was a global conflict that saw significant action by Canadian forces. The war marked a major turning point in the country's military history.

### Canadian Army operations

The Canadian Army played a key role in the Second World War, serving in various capacities around the world.

### Naval operations

The Royal Canadian Navy played a significant role in the Second World War, serving in various capacities around the world.

### Air operations

The Royal Canadian Air Force played a significant role in the Second World War, serving in various capacities around the world.

### Industry and research

The Second World War saw significant developments in industry and research in Canada, with the country playing a major role in the production of war materials.

## Cold War

The Cold War was a period of significant tension and competition between the United States and the Soviet Union. Canada played a major role in the Cold War, serving as a key ally of the United States.

### Korean War

Canada played a role in the Korean War, serving as part of the United Nations Command.

### Forces in Europe

Canada maintained a significant military presence in Europe during the Cold War, serving as part of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).

### Unification of Canada's military

The Canadian military was unified in 1968, with the creation of the Canadian Forces.

### October Crisis

The October Crisis was a significant event in Canadian history, with the country experiencing a period of domestic terrorism and the imposition of martial law.

### Vietnam War

Canada played a role in the Vietnam War, serving as part of the International Commission of Control and Supervision.

## Post-Cold War

The post-Cold War period saw significant changes and developments in the Canadian military.

### Oka Crisis

The Oka Crisis was a significant event in Canadian history, with the country experiencing a period of domestic conflict and the deployment of the military.

### Gulf War

Canada played a role in the Gulf War, serving as part of the international coalition.

### Somali Civil War

Canada played a role in the Somali Civil War, serving as part of the United Nations Operation in Somalia.

### Yugoslav Wars

Canada played a role in the Yugoslav Wars, serving as part of the United Nations Protection Force.

# 21st century

## War in Afghanistan

Canada played a role in the War in Afghanistan, serving as part of the International Security Assistance Force (ISAF).

## Libyan Civil War

Canada played a role in the Libyan Civil War, serving as part of the international coalition.

## Mali War

Canada played a role in the Mali War, serving as part of the French-led intervention.

## War against the Islamic State

Canada played a role in the War against the Islamic State, serving as part of the international coalition.

# Peacekeeping efforts

Canada has a long history of peacekeeping, serving as part of various United Nations missions around the world.
