article:
The Masked Singer (American TV series) season 7

The seventh season of the American television series The Masked Singer premiered on March 9, 2022, and concluded on May 18, 2022. The season featured a new cast of celebrity contestants competing against each other in a singing competition while wearing elaborate costumes and masks to conceal their identities.

# Panelists and host

The panel of judges for season 7 consisted of Ken Jeong, Jenny McCarthy Wahlberg, Nicole Scherzinger, and Robin Thicke. The show was hosted by Nick Cannon, who also served as an executive producer.

# Contestants

The contestants for season 7 included:

* The Firefly (Teyana Taylor)
* The Ringmaster (Hayley Orrantia)
* The Prince (Cheyenne Jackson)
* The Bull (Todrick Hall)
* The Skunk (Faith Evans)
* The Lemur (Heidi Klum)
* The Cyclops (Katy Perry)
* The Firefighter (Gloria Gaynor)
* The McTerrier (Daniel Radcliffe)
* The Thingamajig (Victor Oladipo)
* The Space Cowboy (Jason Mraz)
* The Black Swan (JoJo Siwa)

# Episodes

## Week 1 (March 9)

The season premiere featured the first group of contestants performing. The Firefly, The Ringmaster, The Prince, and The Bull performed in the first episode. The Firefly won the audience vote, and The Ringmaster was eliminated.

## Week 2 (March 16)

The second episode featured the remaining contestants from the first group, as well as the introduction of new contestants, The Skunk, The Lemur, and The Cyclops. The Skunk won the audience vote, and The Lemur was eliminated.

## Week 3 (March 23)

The third episode featured the contestants from the second group, as well as the introduction of new contestants, The Firefighter, The McTerrier, and The Thingamajig. The Firefighter won the audience vote, and The McTerrier was eliminated.

## Week 4 (March 30)

The fourth episode featured the contestants from the third group, as well as the introduction of new contestants, The Space Cowboy, The Black Swan, and The Bull. The Space Cowboy won the audience vote, and The Black Swan was eliminated.

## Week 5 (April 6)

The fifth episode featured the contestants from the fourth group, as well as the introduction of new contestants, The Skunk, The Lemur, and The Cyclops. The Skunk won the audience vote, and The Lemur was eliminated.

## Week 6 (April 13)

The sixth episode featured the contestants from the fifth group, as well as the introduction of new contestants, The Firefly, The Ringmaster, and The Prince. The Firefly won the audience vote, and The Ringmaster was eliminated.

## Week 7 (April 20)

The seventh episode featured the contestants from the sixth group, as well as the introduction of new contestants, The Bull, The Skunk, and The Firefighter. The Bull won the audience vote, and The Skunk was eliminated.

## Week 8 (April 27)

The eighth episode featured the contestants from the seventh group, as well as the introduction of new contestants, The Space Cowboy, The Black Swan, and The Thingamajig. The Space Cowboy won the audience vote, and The Black Swan was eliminated.

## Week 9 (May 4)

The ninth episode featured the contestants from the eighth group, as well as the introduction of new contestants, The Firefly, The Prince, and The Cyclops. The Firefly won the audience vote, and The Prince was eliminated.

## Week 10 (May 18)

The season finale featured the last three contestants, The Firefly, The Bull, and The Space Cowboy. The Firefly won the audience vote, and was crowned the winner of season 7.

# Ratings

The seventh season of The Masked Singer averaged a 1.3 rating in the 18-49 demographic, and 6.3 million viewers per episode.

# Controversy

The season was marred by controversy when it was revealed that one of the contestants, The McTerrier, had been involved in a plagiarism scandal in the past. The show's producers were criticized for not disclosing this information to the audience.

# Notes

* The season featured several guest judges, including Joel McHale, Will Arnett, and Chrissy Teigen.
* The show's costumes were designed by Marina Toybina, who won an Emmy Award for her work on the show.
* The season's finale was watched by 7.3 million viewers, making it the show's highest-rated episode of the season.

2023 IHF Men's U19 Handball World Championship

The 2023 IHF Men's U19 Handball World Championship is the 9th edition of the IHF Men's U19 World Championship, an international handball tournament organized by the International Handball Federation (IHF). The tournament will be held in North Macedonia and Greece from 2 to 13 August 2023.

# Bidding process
The bidding process for the 2023 IHF Men's U19 Handball World Championship began in 2019, with several countries expressing interest in hosting the tournament. After a thorough evaluation process, the IHF announced that North Macedonia and Greece would co-host the championship.

# Qualification
The qualification process for the 2023 IHF Men's U19 Handball World Championship took place from 2019 to 2022. A total of 32 teams qualified for the tournament, with the top teams from each continent earning a spot. The qualification process included continental championships, as well as wild card entries.

# Draw
The draw for the 2023 IHF Men's U19 Handball World Championship took place on 30 June 2023. The 32 teams were divided into eight groups of four teams each, with the top teams from each group advancing to the main round.

# Referees
The IHF appointed a total of 16 referee pairs to officiate the 2023 IHF Men's U19 Handball World Championship. The referees underwent a rigorous selection process, with the top officials from around the world earning a spot at the tournament.

# Preliminary round
The preliminary round of the 2023 IHF Men's U19 Handball World Championship took place from 2 to 5 August 2023. The 32 teams were divided into eight groups of four teams each, with the top teams from each group advancing to the main round.

## Group A
Group A consisted of teams from Egypt, Qatar, Norway, and Chile. Egypt topped the group, followed by Norway in second place.

## Group B
Group B consisted of teams from Denmark, France, Japan, and Argentina. Denmark topped the group, followed by France in second place.

## Group C
Group C consisted of teams from Spain, Sweden, Brazil, and Tunisia. Spain topped the group, followed by Sweden in second place.

## Group D
Group D consisted of teams from Germany, Croatia, United States, and Saudi Arabia. Germany topped the group, followed by Croatia in second place.

## Group E
Group E consisted of teams from Slovenia, Portugal, Algeria, and China. Slovenia topped the group, followed by Portugal in second place.

## Group F
Group F consisted of teams from North Macedonia, Greece, Iceland, and Morocco. North Macedonia topped the group, followed by Greece in second place.

## Group G
Group G consisted of teams from Hungary, Poland, Iran, and Cuba. Hungary topped the group, followed by Poland in second place.

## Group H
Group H consisted of teams from South Korea, Australia, Uruguay, and Georgia. South Korea topped the group, followed by Australia in second place.

# President's Cup
The President's Cup is a secondary tournament that takes place during the IHF Men's U19 Handball World Championship. The teams that finish last in each group during the preliminary round compete in the President's Cup.

## Group I
Group I consisted of teams from Chile, Japan, Tunisia, and Saudi Arabia. Chile topped the group, followed by Japan in second place.

## Group II
Group II consisted of teams from Argentina, Brazil, Algeria, and United States. Argentina topped the group, followed by Brazil in second place.

## Group III
Group III consisted of teams from Qatar, Morocco, Cuba, and Georgia. Qatar topped the group, followed by Morocco in second place.

## Group IV
Group IV consisted of teams from Norway, France, Iceland, and Australia. Norway topped the group, followed by France in second place.

# Main round
The main round of the 2023 IHF Men's U19 Handball World Championship took place from 6 to 9 August 2023. The top teams from each group during the preliminary round competed in the main round.

## Group I
Group I consisted of teams from Egypt, Denmark, Spain, and Slovenia. Egypt topped the group, followed by Denmark in second place.

## Group II
Group II consisted of teams from Germany, North Macedonia, Hungary, and South Korea. Germany topped the group, followed by North Macedonia in second place.

## Group III
Group III consisted of teams from Norway, France, Sweden, and Croatia. Norway topped the group, followed by France in second place.

## Group IV
Group IV consisted of teams from Portugal, Greece, Poland, and Qatar. Portugal topped the group, followed by Greece in second place.

# Classification games

article:
Otto von Bolschwing
================

Otto von Bolschwing was a German SS officer, spy, and businessman who played a significant role in the Nazi regime during World War II. His life was marked by his involvement in espionage, his connections to high-ranking Nazi officials, and his post-war activities with the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA). This article explores von Bolschwing's life, from his early days in Germany to his later years in the United States.

Early life and Nazi career
---------------------------

### Early life and business ventures

Otto von Bolschwing was born on October 15, 1909, in Schönbruch, East Prussia, German Empire (now Poland). He came from a noble family and was the youngest of three children. After completing his secondary education, von Bolschwing went on to study law and economics at the University of Berlin. During his university years, he became involved with the Nazi Party and joined the SA (Sturmabteilung) in 1930.

In 1931, von Bolschwing founded his own business venture, a textile company in Berlin. However, his business failed, and he was forced to declare bankruptcy in 1933. It was during this time that von Bolschwing began to focus on his Nazi career, joining the SS (Schutzstaffel) in 1934.

### Mandatory Palestine

In 1934, von Bolschwing traveled to Mandatory Palestine, where he became involved with the Haganah, a Jewish paramilitary organization. He worked as a spy for the Haganah, gathering intelligence on Arab movements and reporting back to the organization. Von Bolschwing's experiences in Palestine would later influence his views on the Jewish people and shape his role in the Nazi regime.

### Office of Jewish Affairs

Upon his return to Germany, von Bolschwing was appointed to the Office of Jewish Affairs, a department within the SS responsible for handling Jewish matters. He worked closely with Adolf Eichmann, who would later become the architect of the Holocaust. Von Bolschwing's role in the Office of Jewish Affairs was to gather intelligence on Jewish communities and organizations, both within Germany and abroad.

World War II
------------

### Romania

In 1940, von Bolschwing was sent to Romania, where he worked as a liaison officer between the German military and the Romanian government. He played a key role in negotiating the transfer of Romanian Jews to German-controlled territories. Ben Roberts-Smith
================

Ben Roberts-Smith is a former Australian Army soldier and recipient of the Victoria Cross for Australia, the country's highest military honor. His military career spanned over 20 years, during which he served in several conflicts, including the War in Afghanistan. After leaving the military, Roberts-Smith transitioned to a corporate career and has been involved in various other activities. However, his post-military life has been marred by controversy, including war crime allegations and a high-profile defamation suit.

Early Life and Family
--------------------

Ben Roberts-Smith was born on November 1, 1978, in Perth, Western Australia. He grew up in a military family and was educated at Hale School in Perth. Roberts-Smith's father, Len Roberts-Smith, was a Vietnam War veteran and a successful businessman. His mother, Sue Roberts-Smith, was a schoolteacher. Roberts-Smith has two siblings, a brother, and a sister.

Military Career
----------------

Roberts-Smith enlisted in the Australian Army in 1996 and underwent recruit training at the Army Recruit Training Centre in Wagga Wagga, New South Wales. He was assigned to the 3rd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (3 RAR), and later transferred to the Special Air Service Regiment (SASR) in 2003. During his time in the SASR, Roberts-Smith served in several conflicts, including the War in Afghanistan.

## Military Decorations

Roberts-Smith's military decorations include the Victoria Cross for Australia, which he was awarded in 2011 for his actions during a firefight in Afghanistan in 2010. He also received the Medal for Gallantry and the Commendation for Distinguished Service. Roberts-Smith was also awarded the United States Army Commendation Medal and the United States Army Achievement Medal.

Corporate Career
-----------------

After leaving the military in 2013, Roberts-Smith transitioned to a corporate career. He worked as a general manager for Seven West Media, a Australian media company, and later became the chief executive officer of the company's digital division. In 2018, Roberts-Smith was appointed as the chief executive officer of the Australian War Memorial.

Other Activities
-----------------

Roberts-Smith has been involved in various other activities, including charity work and public speaking. He has worked with several charities, including the Australian War Memorial and the SAS Resources Trust. Roberts-Smith has also given public talks about his military experiences and has written articles for various publications.

War Crime Allegations
----------------------

In 2020, Roberts-Smith was accused of war crimes by several members of the SASR. The allegations included claims that Roberts-Smith had killed unarmed civilians in Afghanistan and had covered up the incidents. The allegations were investigated by the Australian Federal Police and the Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force.

## Investigation

The investigation into the war crime allegations against Roberts-Smith was led by the Australian Federal Police and the Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force. The investigation found that there was insufficient evidence to charge Roberts-Smith with war crimes. However, the investigation did find that Roberts-Smith had been involved in several incidents in Afghanistan that had resulted in the deaths of unarmed civilians.

Defamation Suit
----------------

In 2020, Roberts-Smith launched a defamation suit against several media outlets, including The Sydney Morning Herald and The Age, over the publication of articles that alleged he had committed war crimes. The suit also named several individuals, including a former SASR soldier who had made the allegations against Roberts-Smith.

## Judgment

In 2022, the defamation suit was heard in the Federal Court of Australia. The court found that the media outlets had defamed Roberts-Smith, but that the defamation was not malicious. The court awarded Roberts-Smith damages of $1 million.

## Appeal

The media outlets appealed the judgment, arguing that the court had erred in finding that the defamation was not malicious. The appeal is currently pending.

Further Controversy
----------------------

Roberts-Smith has been involved in further controversy, including allegations that he had used his position as chief executive officer of the Australian War Memorial to promote his own interests. In 2022, Roberts-Smith resigned as chief executive officer of the Australian War Memorial, citing health reasons.

Personal Life
--------------

Roberts-Smith is married to Emma Roberts-Smith, and the couple has two children. He is a keen sportsman and has competed in several Ironman triathlons. Roberts-Smith is also a keen outdoorsman and has written articles about his hiking and camping experiences.

article:
Super Bowl LVII

Super Bowl LVII was the 57th edition of the Super Bowl, the annual championship game of the National Football League (NFL). The game took place on February 12, 2023, at State Farm Stadium in Glendale, Arizona. The Kansas City Chiefs defeated the Philadelphia Eagles 38-35 in a closely contested game.

Background

### Host selection

On May 23, 2017, the NFL announced that State Farm Stadium in Glendale, Arizona, would host Super Bowl LVII. The stadium, previously known as University of Phoenix Stadium, had previously hosted Super Bowl XLII and Super Bowl XLIX.

### Calls for location change

In 2020, the NFL faced criticism for awarding the Super Bowl to Arizona due to the state's voting laws, which some saw as restrictive. However, the league ultimately decided not to relocate the game.

### Indigenous representation

The NFL partnered with the Inter Tribal Sports Initiative, a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting sports and recreation in Native American communities. The partnership included the creation of a mural featuring Native American artwork and the hosting of a football clinic for Native American youth.

### Stadium playing surface

The playing surface at State Farm Stadium was switched from natural grass to artificial turf in 2022. The new turf, known as "SISGrass," was designed to mimic the look and feel of natural grass.

Teams

### Kansas City Chiefs

The Kansas City Chiefs entered Super Bowl LVII as the American Football Conference (AFC) champions. Led by quarterback Patrick Mahomes, the Chiefs had a 14-3 regular season record and defeated the Jacksonville Jaguars and the Cincinnati Bengals in the playoffs.

### Philadelphia Eagles

The Philadelphia Eagles entered Super Bowl LVII as the National Football Conference (NFC) champions. Led by quarterback Jalen Hurts, the Eagles had a 14-3 regular season record and defeated the New York Giants and the San Francisco 49ers in the playoffs.

### Playoffs

The Chiefs and Eagles both had dominating performances in the playoffs. The Chiefs defeated the Jaguars 27-20 in the Divisional Round and the Bengals 23-20 in the AFC Championship Game. The Eagles defeated the Giants 38-7 in the Divisional Round and the 49ers 31-7 in the NFC Championship Game.

### Pre-game notes

The Chiefs were considered 1.5-point favorites by Las Vegas sportsbooks, while the Eagles were considered the underdogs. The game was expected to be a high-scoring affair, with a projected total of 49.5 points.

Broadcasting

### United States

#### Television

Super Bowl LVII was broadcast on Fox in the United States, with Kevin Burkhardt and Greg Olsen serving as the play-by-play announcer and color commentator, respectively. The broadcast was available in 4K ultra-high definition.

#### Advertising

The cost of a 30-second commercial during Super Bowl LVII was reportedly around $6.5 million. Major brands such as Pepsi, Bud Light, and General Motors aired commercials during the game.

#### Ratings

The Super Bowl LVII broadcast drew an average audience of 118.7 million viewers, making it the most-watched television program of the year.

#### Streaming

The game was available to stream on the Fox Sports app and on various online platforms, including Hulu and YouTube TV.

#### Radio

The game was broadcast on Westwood One radio, with Kevin Harlan and Trent Green serving as the play-by-play announcer and color commentator, respectively.

### International

Super Bowl LVII was broadcast in over 180 countries and territories worldwide, with broadcasts available in multiple languages.

Entertainment

### Pregame

The pregame show featured performances by Babyface, Sheryl Lee Ralph, and the Black Eyed Peas. The national anthem was performed by Chris Stapleton, while the flyover was conducted by the U.S. Air Force.

### Halftime

The halftime show featured a performance by Rihanna, who performed a medley of her hits. The show was widely praised for its high-energy performance and visual effects.

Game summary

### First half

The Eagles received the opening kickoff and drove down to the Chiefs' 10-yard line, where they settled for a field goal. The Chiefs responded with a touchdown drive, capped off by a 22-yard pass from Mahomes to tight end Travis Kelce. The Eagles responded with a touchdown drive of their own, with Hurts scoring on a 1-yard run. The Chiefs added a field goal before halftime, taking a 10-7 lead.

### Second half

The Eagles took the lead on their opening drive of the second half, with Hurts scoring on a 2-yard run. The Chiefs responded with a touchdown drive, with Mahomes scoring on a 1-yard run. The Eagles added a field goal, but the Chiefs took the lead for good on a 5-yard touchdown pass from Mahomes to wide receiver Marquez Valdes-Scantling. The Eagles added a late touchdown, but the Chiefs held on for a 38-35 victory.

The 2022 French legislative election was held on June 12 and 19, 2022, to elect the 577 members of the 16th National Assembly of the French Fifth Republic. The election was held in two rounds, with the first round taking place on June 12 and the second round on June 19. A total of 6,293 candidates contested the election, representing a wide range of parties and movements.

The election saw a significant increase in the number of seats won by the far-right Rassemblement National (RN) party, led by Marine Le Pen, as well as a decline in the number of seats held by the center-right Les Républicains (LR) party. The ruling party, La République En Marche! (LREM), led by Emmanuel Macron, lost a significant number of seats, although it remained the largest party in the National Assembly.

article:
Impeachment Inquiry into Joe Biden

The impeachment inquiry into Joe Biden refers to the investigation conducted by the United States House of Representatives into allegations of misconduct by President Joe Biden. The inquiry was initiated in September 2022, and it has been the subject of intense debate and controversy in the United States.

#Background

The impeachment inquiry into Joe Biden was sparked by allegations of misconduct related to his handling of foreign policy, particularly with regards to Ukraine. In August 2022, a whistleblower complaint was filed with the Inspector General of the Intelligence Community, alleging that President Biden had improperly used his authority to pressure the Ukrainian government to investigate a political rival. The complaint also alleged that the President had withheld military aid to Ukraine in order to coerce the Ukrainian government into investigating the rival.

The allegations against President Biden were initially made public in September 2022, and they quickly gained widespread attention in the media. The allegations were denied by the President and his administration, but they were seen as potentially serious enough to warrant an investigation by Congress.

#Initiation of the inquiry

The impeachment inquiry into Joe Biden was formally initiated on September 24, 2022, when Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi announced that the House would be launching an investigation into the allegations against the President. The inquiry was to be led by the House Intelligence Committee, with assistance from the House Foreign Affairs Committee and the House Oversight Committee.

The initiation of the inquiry was met with intense debate and controversy, with Republicans arguing that the inquiry was an attempt to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election and Democrats arguing that it was necessary to hold the President accountable for his actions.

#House committee investigations

The House Intelligence Committee, led by Chairman Adam Schiff, took the lead in investigating the allegations against President Biden. The committee conducted a series of closed-door depositions with witnesses, including officials from the State Department, the Defense Department, and the National Security Council.

The committee also conducted a series of public hearings, featuring testimony from witnesses such as Alexander Smirnov, a former National Security Council staffer. The hearings were widely covered in the media and were seen as a key part of the impeachment inquiry.

##Witness credibility

One of the key issues in the impeachment inquiry was the credibility of the witnesses who testified before the House Intelligence Committee. Republicans argued that many of the witnesses were biased against the President and had a personal stake in the outcome of the inquiry.

One witness who came under particular scrutiny was Alexander Smirnov, a former National Security Council staffer who had worked on Ukraine policy. Smirnov testified before the committee in November 2022, and his testimony was seen as potentially damaging to the President.

Smirnov testified that he had been present at a meeting between the President and Ukrainian officials, and that the President had explicitly linked military aid to Ukraine to the Ukrainian government's willingness to investigate a political rival. Smirnov's testimony was corroborated by other witnesses, but it was disputed by the President and his administration.

#Responses

The impeachment inquiry into Joe Biden was met with a range of responses from different groups and individuals.

##Republican reaction

Republicans were strongly opposed to the impeachment inquiry, arguing that it was an attempt to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election. Many Republicans argued that the allegations against the President were unfounded and that the inquiry was a waste of time and resources.

##Democratic reaction

Democrats, on the other hand, were strongly supportive of the impeachment inquiry, arguing that it was necessary to hold the President accountable for his actions. Many Democrats argued that the allegations against the President were serious and deserved to be investigated.

##Reaction from academics

Academics and legal experts were also divided on the impeachment inquiry, with some arguing that it was justified and others arguing that it was not.

Some academics argued that the allegations against the President were serious enough to warrant an impeachment inquiry, and that the inquiry was necessary to uphold the rule of law and protect the Constitution.

Others argued that the impeachment inquiry was an attempt to politicize the impeachment process, and that it was not justified by the evidence.

#Analysis

The impeachment inquiry into Joe Biden was a complex and multifaceted process, and it raised a range of legal and constitutional issues.

##Legal standing

One of the key issues in the impeachment inquiry was the question of whether the President had committed an impeachable offense. The Constitution provides that the President can be impeached for "treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors," but it does not define what these terms mean.

Some legal experts argued that the allegations against the President were serious enough to warrant impeachment, while others argued that they did not meet the constitutional standard for an impeachable offense.

article:
SOS (SZA album)
================

SOS is the second studio album by American R&B singer SZA, released on December 9, 2022, through Top Dawg Entertainment and RCA Records. The album features guest appearances from Don Toliver, Phoebe Bridgers, Travis Scott, and Ol' Dirty Bastard.

Background
----------

SZA had been working on her second studio album since 2017, but the project was delayed multiple times due to personal and creative issues. In a 2020 interview with Rolling Stone, SZA revealed that she had been struggling with writer's block and was feeling pressure from her record label to release new music. However, she eventually found inspiration and began working on the album in earnest.

Writing and production
--------------------

SOS was written and produced by SZA and a variety of collaborators, including Rodney Jerkins, Don Toliver, and Babyface. The album features a diverse range of styles and influences, from hip hop and R&B to rock and electronic music. SZA has stated that she drew inspiration from a wide range of sources, including her personal life, relationships, and social issues.

Composition
------------

SOS is a 23-track album that features a mix of upbeat and introspective songs. The album's sound is characterized by SZA's soulful vocals, introspective lyrics, and genre-bending production. The album's first half features more upbeat tracks, such as "Kill Bill" and "Seek & Destroy," while the second half is more introspective and emotional.

Title and artwork
----------------

The title of the album, SOS, is a reference to the distress signal used in emergency situations. SZA has stated that the title reflects her own feelings of distress and overwhelm during the creation of the album. The album's artwork features a photograph of SZA taken by actor and photographer, Renell Medrano.

Promotion
----------

SZA promoted SOS with a series of singles and music videos, including "Kill Bill," "Seek & Destroy," and "Nobody Gets Me." She also performed on Saturday Night Live and at various music festivals, including Coachella and Glastonbury.

Critical reception
-----------------

### Reviews

SOS received widespread critical acclaim upon its release. Reviewers praised SZA's vocals, songwriting, and genre-bending production. Rolling Stone described the album as "a masterpiece" and praised SZA's "soulful, genre-bending sound." Pitchfork described the album as "a sprawling, ambitious album" and praised SZA's "emotional honesty."

### Year-end rankings

Awards
------

SOS was nominated for several awards, including the Grammy Award for Album of the Year and the BET Award for Album of the Year.

Commercial performance

The 2023 PDC World Darts Championship is one of the most prestigious events in the darts calendar, attracting the best players from around the world. The tournament features a total of 96 players competing in a knockout format, with the winner being crowned the world champion.

The total prize money for the 2023 PDC World Darts Championship is £2.5 million, with the winner receiving £500,000. The runner-up will receive £250,000, and the semi-finalists will receive £100,000 each. The prize money is distributed as follows:

2022 World Men's Curling Championship

The 2022 World Men's Curling Championship was the 64th edition of the World Men's Curling Championship, held from April 2 to 10, 2022, at the Orleans Arena in Las Vegas, Nevada, United States. The championship featured 13 teams from around the world competing for the title of world champion.

# Qualification

The qualification process for the 2022 World Men's Curling Championship was based on the results of the 2021 European Curling Championships, the 2021 Pacific-Asia Curling Championships, and the 2021 Americas Challenge. The top six teams from the 2021 European Curling Championships, the top two teams from the 2021 Pacific-Asia Curling Championships, and the top two teams from the 2021 Americas Challenge qualified directly for the championship. In addition, two teams qualified through the 2022 World Qualification Event, held in January 2022.

## Russian Participation

Due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the World Curling Federation (WCF) announced that it would not allow Russian athletes to compete under the Russian flag at the 2022 World Men's Curling Championship. Instead, Russian athletes were allowed to compete as "Russian Curling Federation" (RCF) under the Olympic flag.

article:
The Kashmir Files
================

The Kashmir Files is a 2022 Indian Hindi-language drama film written and directed by Vivek Ranjan Agnihotri. The film is based on the exodus of Kashmiri Pandits from Kashmir during the Kashmir Insurgency in the early 1990s. The film premiered at the 53rd International Film Festival of India in November 2022 and was released theatrically in India on March 11, 2022.

Plot
-----

The Kashmir Files is based on real-life events and tells the story of the migration of Kashmiri Pandits from Kashmir in the 1990s. The film follows the story of a young Kashmiri Pandit named Krishna, who is a student at the University of Kashmir. Krishna's life takes a turn when he discovers the truth about the exodus of Kashmiri Pandits and the atrocities committed against them. The film explores themes of identity, community, and the struggle for justice.

Cast
-----

* Anupam Kher as Pushkar Nath Pandit
* Darshan Kumar as Krishna Pandit

* Sourav Verma as Sharda Pandit
* Atul Srivastava as Mr. Dhar
* Bhasha Sumbli as Jaya Pandit
* Prakash Belawadi as Mr. Dhar's colleague
* Puneet Issar as DGP
* Atul Kumar as Prof. Radhika's colleague
* Amaan Iqbal as Imran
* Saurabh Verma as Vivek

Production
------------

The Kashmir Files was written and directed by Vivek Ranjan Agnihotri. The film was produced by Zee Studios, Abhishek Agarwal Arts, and I am Buddha Production. The film was shot in various locations in India, including Kashmir, Delhi, and Mumbai. The film's music was composed by Rohit Sharma, and the lyrics were written by Manoj Muntashir.

Release
--------

### Certification

### Litigations

### Theatrical release

The Kashmir Files was released theatrically in India on March 11, 2022. The film was released in over 600 screens across the country.

### Home media

The film was released on various home media platforms, including Amazon Prime Video, ZEE5, and YouTube.

Government and ruling party support
------------------------------------

The Kashmir Files received support from the Indian government and the ruling party. The film's director, Vivek Ranjan Agnihotri, met with Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Home Minister Amit Shah before the film's release. The government also provided the film with a special exemption from the Goods and Services Tax (GST).

Reception
----------

### Critical reception

The Kashmir Files received mixed reviews from critics. Some critics praised the film's performances, direction, and music, while others criticized the film's portrayal of Kashmiri Muslims and the film's historical accuracy. The film holds a rating of 7.5/10 on IMDB.

### International Film Festival of India

The Kashmir Files was screened at the 53rd International Film Festival of India in November 2022. The film received a standing ovation at the festival.

### Reception by Kashmiri Pandits

The Kashmir Files received a mixed response from Kashmiri Pandits. Some Kashmiri Pandits praised the film for highlighting the atrocities committed against their community, while others criticized the film for its portrayal of Kashmiri Muslims and the film's historical accuracy.

Tornado Outbreak of March 24–27, 2023

A devastating tornado outbreak affected the southeastern United States from March 24 to March 27, 2023, causing widespread destruction and loss of life. The outbreak was characterized by a series of intense tornadoes that touched down across multiple states, including Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, and Tennessee. This article provides an overview of the meteorological conditions that led to the outbreak, the confirmed tornadoes, non-tornadic effects, and the aftermath of the event.

# Meteorological Synopsis

## March 24–25

A strong low-pressure system developed over the southern Great Plains on March 24, bringing with it a mass of warm, moist air from the Gulf of Mexico. As the system moved eastward, it interacted with a cold front that was pushing southward from Canada, creating a volatile mix of warm and cold air that fueled the development of thunderstorms. The Storm Prediction Center (SPC) had issued a moderate risk (4/5) for severe thunderstorms across parts of the Southeast, including Mississippi and Alabama. As the storms developed, they quickly became supercellular, producing large hail, damaging winds, and tornadoes.

## March 26–27

The low-pressure system continued to move eastward, bringing the associated cold front into the Southeast. The SPC had issued a high risk (5/5) for severe thunderstorms across parts of Georgia and Tennessee, including the Atlanta metropolitan area. The storms that developed on March 26 and 27 were more intense than those on March 24 and 25, producing multiple long-lived tornadoes that caused significant damage and loss of life.

# Confirmed Tornadoes

## March 24 Event

A total of 15 tornadoes were confirmed on March 24, with the majority of them touching down in Mississippi. The strongest tornado of the day was an EF3 that touched down in Winston County, causing significant damage and injuring several people.

## March 25 Event

A total of 12 tornadoes were confirmed on March 25, with the majority of them touching down in Alabama. The strongest tornado of the day was an EF2 that touched down in Cullman County, causing significant damage and injuring several people.

## March 26 Event

## March 27 Event

A total of 15 tornadoes were confirmed on March 27, with the majority of them touching down in Tennessee. The strongest tornado of the day was an EF3 that touched down in Putnam County, causing significant damage and injuring several people.

## Rolling Fork–Midnight–Silver City, Mississippi

A devastating EF4 tornado touched down in Rolling Fork, Mississippi, on March 24, causing catastrophic damage and killing several people. The tornado was on the ground for over 60 miles, affecting multiple communities in Sharkey and Humphreys counties. The tornado was particularly destructive in the town of Rolling Fork, where entire city blocks were reduced to rubble.

## Black Hawk–Winona, Mississippi

A long-lived EF3 tornado touched down in Black Hawk, Mississippi, on March 24, causing significant damage and injuring several people. The tornado was on the ground for over 40 miles, affecting multiple communities in Carroll and Montgomery counties.

## Egypt–New Wren–Amory–Smithville, Mississippi

A devastating EF4 tornado touched down in Egypt, Mississippi, on March 24, causing catastrophic damage and killing several people. The tornado was on the ground for over 50 miles, affecting multiple communities in Monroe and Itawamba counties. The tornado was particularly destructive in the town of Amory, where entire city blocks were reduced to rubble.

## North West Point–Smiths Mill–Pine Mountain, Georgia

A long-lived EF4 tornado touched down in North West Point, Georgia, on March 26, causing catastrophic damage and killing several people. The tornado was on the ground for over 60 miles, affecting multiple communities in Troup and Harris counties. The tornado was particularly destructive in the town of Pine Mountain, where entire city blocks were reduced to rubble.

# Non-Tornadic Effects

In addition to the tornadoes, the outbreak also produced significant non-tornadic effects, including large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding. The storms that developed on March 24 and 25 produced large hail that caused significant damage to vehicles and buildings. The storms that developed on March 26 and 27 produced damaging winds that caused widespread power outages and property damage. Flash flooding was also a significant concern, particularly in areas where the storms produced heavy rainfall.

# Aftermath

The aftermath of the outbreak was marked by a massive response effort from emergency management officials, first responders, and volunteers. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) deployed teams to the affected areas to assess the damage and provide support to those affected.

## Political Response

The governor of Mississippi declared a state of emergency in response to the outbreak, mobilizing the state's National Guard to assist with response efforts. The governor of Alabama also declared a state of emergency, deploying state resources to support affected communities. The governor of Georgia declared a state of emergency, mobilizing state resources to support affected communities.

## Mississippi

The state of Mississippi was particularly hard hit by the outbreak, with multiple communities affected by tornadoes. The town of Rolling Fork was particularly devastated, with entire city blocks reduced to rubble.

### Rolling Fork

The town of Rolling Fork was one of the hardest hit communities in the state, with over 50 homes destroyed and multiple businesses affected. The town's infrastructure was severely damaged, with power lines and water mains severed. Emergency management officials worked quickly to establish a shelter for those affected, providing food, water, and medical care.

### Amory

The town of Amory was also severely affected by the outbreak, with over 20 homes destroyed and multiple businesses affected. The town's infrastructure was severely damaged, with power lines and water mains severed. Emergency management officials worked quickly to establish a shelter for those affected, providing food, water, and medical care.

article:
2022 Swedish General Election

The 2022 Swedish general election was held on September 11, 2022, to elect members of the Riksdag, Sweden's national legislature. The election saw the participation of eight political parties, with the Social Democratic Party, led by Magdalena Andersson, seeking to retain its position as the largest party in the Riksdag.

Background
----------

### Löfven's Government

The 2018 Swedish general election resulted in a hung parliament, with the Social Democratic Party, led by Stefan Löfven, winning the most seats but failing to secure a majority. After a prolonged government formation process, Löfven formed a minority government consisting of the Social Democrats and the Green Party. The government relied on support from the Centre Party and the Liberals to pass legislation.

### Andersson's Government

In August 2021, Stefan Löfven announced his intention to resign as Prime Minister and leader of the Social Democratic Party. Magdalena Andersson, the party's deputy leader and Minister of Finance, succeeded Löfven as party leader and Prime Minister. Andersson formed a new government, which retained the same composition as Löfven's government.

Electoral System
----------------

### Political Parties

Eight parties participated in the 2022 Swedish general election:

1. Social Democratic Party (S)
2. Moderate Party (M)
3. Sweden Democrats (SD)
4. Centre Party (C)
5. Left Party (V)
6. Green Party (MP)
7. Liberals (L)
8. Christian Democrats (KD)

### Pre-election Composition

The pre-election composition of the Riksdag was as follows:

* Social Democratic Party: 100 seats
* Moderate Party: 70 seats
* Sweden Democrats: 62 seats
* Centre Party: 31 seats
* Left Party: 27 seats
* Green Party: 16 seats
* Liberals: 20 seats
* Christian Democrats: 22 seats

Campaign
---------

### Issues

The 2022 Swedish general election campaign focused on several key issues, including:

* Climate change and energy policy
* Immigration and integration
* Healthcare and social welfare
* Education and labor market policy
* Crime and justice

### Party Campaigns

Each party ran its own campaign, with the Social Democrats focusing on their record in government and their plans for the future. The Moderate Party campaigned on a platform of tax cuts and increased spending on defense and law enforcement. The Sweden Democrats focused on immigration and crime, while the Centre Party and Liberals emphasized their commitment to environmental protection and social justice.

### Slogans

* Social Democratic Party: "A Sweden for All"
* Moderate Party: "Sweden's Future Begins Now"
* Sweden Democrats: "Sweden First"
* Centre Party: "For a Greener and More Equal Sweden"
* Left Party: "Not for Sale"
* Green Party: "The Climate Party"
* Liberals: "For a Free and Open Society"
* Christian Democrats: "Faith in the Future"

### Debates

Several televised debates were held during the campaign, featuring the leaders of the eight participating parties. The debates focused on key issues such as climate change, immigration, and healthcare.

Opinion Polls
-------------

Opinion polls were conducted regularly throughout the campaign, with the Social Democrats consistently leading the Moderate Party and Sweden Democrats. However, the polls also suggested that the election would be closely contested, with several parties vying for third place.

Results
--------

### By Bloc

The results of the 2022 Swedish general election were as follows:

* Red-Green Bloc (S, V, MP): 49.6% (175 seats)
* Alliance Bloc (M, C, L, KD): 49.4% (173 seats)
* Sweden Democrats: 20.6% (73 seats)

### Voter Demographics

The election saw a high turnout among young voters and those living in urban areas. The Social Democrats performed strongly among women and those with higher levels of education, while the Moderate Party and Sweden Democrats did well among men and those living in rural areas.

### By Constituency

The results varied significantly by constituency, with the Social Democrats performing strongly in urban areas such as Stockholm and Gothenburg. The Moderate Party and Sweden Democrats did well in rural areas, particularly in the south and west of the country.

### Seat Distribution

The final seat distribution was as follows:

* Social Democratic Party: 107 seats
* Moderate Party: 68 seats
* Sweden Democrats: 73 seats
* Centre Party: 24 seats
* Left Party: 24 seats
* Green Party: 18 seats
* Liberals: 16 seats
* Christian Democrats: 19 seats

### Maps

Maps of the election results showed a clear divide between urban and rural areas, with the Social Democrats performing strongly in cities and the Moderate Party and Sweden Democrats doing well in rural areas.

Aftermath
---------

### Government Formation

The 2022 Swedish general election resulted in a hung parliament, with no party or bloc having a majority. Magdalena Andersson, the leader of the Social Democratic Party, was tasked with forming a new government. After several weeks of negotiations, Andersson formed a minority government consisting of the Social Democrats and the Green Party, with support from the Centre Party and Liberals.

Kang Full

Kang Full is a South Korean cartoonist, writer, and artist, best known for his work in the webtoon industry. With a career spanning over two decades, Kang has established himself as one of the most successful and influential cartoonists in Korea, with a wide range of works that have captivated audiences of all ages.

#Early life and education

Kang Full was born on January 12, 1974, in Seoul, South Korea. Growing up in a family of modest means, Kang developed an early interest in art and storytelling. He spent most of his childhood drawing and creating his own stories, which eventually led him to pursue a career in cartooning. Kang attended Hongik University, where he studied fine arts and honed his skills as a cartoonist.

#Career

##Early career

Kang Full began his career in the late 1990s, working as an assistant to several established cartoonists. During this time, he honed his skills and developed his unique style, which blended elements of humor, satire, and social commentary. In the early 2000s, Kang started creating his own webtoons, which quickly gained popularity among Korean audiences.

##Career breakthrough

Kang's breakthrough came in 2002 with the launch of his webtoon "Apartment", which told the story of a young couple living in a small apartment in Seoul. The webtoon's relatable characters, witty dialogue, and poignant storylines resonated with audiences, and it quickly became one of the most popular webtoons in Korea.

##Serialized fiction webtoons

Throughout the 2000s, Kang continued to create serialized fiction webtoons, including "Moving" (2003), "Bridge" (2005), and "Hidden" (2007). These webtoons solidified Kang's reputation as a masterful storyteller and cemented his position as one of the leading figures in the Korean webtoon industry.

##Kang's action series: Moving, Bridge, and Hidden

Kang's action series, which includes "Moving", "Bridge", and "Hidden", is notable for its fast-paced action sequences, complex characters, and intricate plotlines. These webtoons have been praised for their technical skill and narrative depth, and have helped to establish Kang as a leading figure in the Korean action genre.

#Other work

##Children picture books

In addition to his webtoons, Kang has also created several children's picture books, including "The Little Rabbit" (2009) and "The Magic Pencil" (2011). These books have been praised for their imaginative storytelling and colorful illustrations, and have become popular among Korean children.

##The Kang Full Cartoon Alley

In 2015, Kang launched the Kang Full Cartoon Alley, a website that features a collection of his webtoons, including "Apartment", "Moving", and "Bridge". The website also includes a blog, where Kang shares his thoughts on cartooning, writing, and art.

#Working style

##Art Style/Technique and materials

Kang's art style is characterized by its simplicity, elegance, and expressiveness. He uses a range of techniques, including digital painting, ink, and watercolor, to create his distinctive illustrations. Kang is known for his attention to detail and his ability to convey complex emotions through simple, yet powerful, images.

##Kang Full Universe

Kang's works are set in a shared universe, which he has dubbed the "Kang Full Universe". This universe is characterized by its complex characters, interconnected storylines, and sprawling world-building. The Kang Full Universe has been praised for its depth, richness, and consistency, and has become a hallmark of Kang's work.

#Personal life

Kang Full is known to be private about his personal life, but it is clear that he is deeply passionate about his work and is committed to creating stories that resonate with audiences. He is active on social media, where he engages with fans and shares updates about his latest projects.

Government and intergovernmental reactions to the Russian invasion of Ukraine

The Russian invasion of Ukraine, which began on February 24, 2022, has sparked widespread condemnation and concern from governments and intergovernmental organizations around the world. The international community has been swift in responding to the crisis, with many countries imposing economic sanctions on Russia, providing military aid to Ukraine, and calling for a ceasefire.

# Ukraine

The Ukrainian government has been vocal in its condemnation of the Russian invasion, with President Volodymyr Zelenskyy calling it an "act of aggression" and a "war crime." Ukraine has also appealed to the international community for support, with Zelenskyy urging countries to impose sanctions on Russia and provide military aid to Ukraine. The Ukrainian government has also established a number of facilities to provide humanitarian aid to those affected by the conflict.

# Russia

The Russian government has defended its actions in Ukraine, with President Vladimir Putin claiming that the invasion is aimed at "denazifying" Ukraine and protecting ethnic Russians. Russia has also imposed its own sanctions on Ukraine, and has accused the West of interfering in its internal affairs. 2021–2023 ICC World Test Championship

The 2021–2023 ICC World Test Championship is the second edition of the ICC World Test Championship, an international Test cricket tournament contested by the 12 Full Member nations of the International Cricket Council (ICC). The tournament began on 4 August 2021 and is scheduled to conclude on 8 July 2023.

Format

The tournament features nine Test-playing nations competing in a league format, with each side playing six home and six away series over a two-year period. The top two teams in the league table will compete in the final at Lord's Cricket Ground in London.

Points system

The points system for the tournament is as follows:

* 12 points for a win
* 6 points for a draw
* 0 points for a loss
* 6 points for a tie

Additionally, teams can earn bonus points for winning matches within a certain number of days. The bonus points system is as follows:

* 1 bonus point for winning a match in 2 days
* 1 bonus point for winning a match in 3 days

Ranil Wickremesinghe

Ranil Wickremesinghe is a Sri Lankan politician who has been serving as the President of Sri Lanka since 2022. He previously served as the Prime Minister of Sri Lanka from 1993 to 1994, 2001 to 2004, and 2015 to 2019. Wickremesinghe has been a member of the United National Party (UNP) since 1977 and has held various leadership positions within the party.

#Early life and education

Ranil Wickremesinghe was born on March 24, 1949, in Colombo, Ceylon (now Sri Lanka). He comes from a prominent family of politicians and lawyers. His father, Esmond Wickremesinghe, was a lawyer and a member of the State Council of Ceylon. Wickremesinghe's maternal grandfather, D.R. Wijewardena, was a wealthy businessman and the founder of the Lake House newspaper group.

Wickremesinghe received his primary education at the Royal College, Colombo. He later attended the University of Ceylon, where he earned a degree in law. Wickremesinghe was called to the bar in 1972 and began his career as a lawyer.

#Political career

Wickremesinghe entered politics in 1977, when he joined the United National Party (UNP). He quickly rose through the ranks of the party and became a key advisor to President J.R. Jayewardene.

##Batalanda incident

In 1991, Wickremesinghe was involved in a controversy surrounding the Batalanda detention center, where several opposition politicians and activists were detained and allegedly tortured. Wickremesinghe, who was then the Minister of Education, was accused of having knowledge of the torture and failing to take action to stop it. The incident damaged Wickremesinghe's reputation and led to widespread criticism of the UNP government.

##First premiership (1993–1994)

In 1993, Wickremesinghe became the Prime Minister of Sri Lanka, following the assassination of President Ranasinghe Premadasa. Wickremesinghe's premiership was marked by a series of economic reforms aimed at liberalizing the economy and attracting foreign investment.

##Opposition (1994–2001)

###1999 presidential election

In 1999, Wickremesinghe ran for president but lost to Chandrika Kumaratunga of the People's Alliance. Wickremesinghe's defeat was seen as a setback for the UNP, and he faced criticism from within the party for his leadership style.

##Second premiership (2001–2004)

In 2001, Wickremesinghe became prime minister again, following the UNP's victory in the parliamentary elections. Wickremesinghe's second premiership was marked by a series of peace talks with the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE), which had been fighting a separatist war against the government.

###Peace talks

Wickremesinghe's government signed a ceasefire agreement with the LTTE in 2002, which led to a period of relative peace in the country. However, the peace talks ultimately failed, and fighting resumed in 2006.

##Opposition (2004–2015)

###2005 presidential election

In 2005, Wickremesinghe ran for president again but lost to Mahinda Rajapaksa of the United People's Freedom Alliance. Wickremesinghe's defeat was seen as a major setback for the UNP, and he faced criticism from within the party for his leadership style.

###Dissent within the UNP

In 2011, Wickremesinghe faced a leadership challenge from within the UNP, when a group of party members led by Karu Jayasuriya attempted to oust him as party leader. Wickremesinghe ultimately prevailed, but the incident damaged the party's unity.

###End of the civil war and 2010 presidential election

In 2009, the civil war between the government and the LTTE came to an end, with the government emerging victorious. In 2010, Wickremesinghe ran for president again but lost to Mahinda Rajapaksa. Wickremesinghe's defeat was seen as a major setback for the UNP, and he faced criticism from within the party for his leadership style.

##Third, fourth and fifth premierships (2015–2019)

In 2015, Wickremesinghe became prime minister again, following the UNP's victory in the parliamentary elections. Wickremesinghe's third premiership was marked by a series of economic reforms aimed at liberalizing the economy and attracting foreign investment.

###Foreign policy

Wickremesinghe's government pursued a foreign policy aimed at strengthening relations with Western countries and improving relations with India. Wickremesinghe also played a key role in Sri Lanka's accession to the Belt and Road Initiative, a Chinese-led infrastructure development project.

###Government bonds controversy

In 2015, Wickremesinghe's government was embroiled in a controversy surrounding the issuance of government bonds, which led to allegations of corruption and cronyism. The incident damaged Wickremesinghe's reputation and led to widespread criticism of the UNP government.

##Opposition (2019–2022)

In 2019, Wickremesinghe's government was defeated in the presidential election, and he was succeeded as prime minister by Mahinda Rajapaksa. Wickremesinghe became the leader of the opposition and led the UNP in parliament.

##Sixth premiership (2022)

In 2022, Wickremesinghe became prime minister again, following the resignation of Mahinda Rajapaksa. Wickremesinghe's sixth premiership was marked by a series of economic reforms aimed at addressing the country's economic crisis.

#Presidency (2022–2024)

In July 2022, Wickremesinghe was elected as the President of Sri Lanka, following the resignation of Gotabaya Rajapaksa.

##Crackdown on anti-government protests

Wickremesinghe's government has been criticized for its crackdown on anti-government protests, which have been taking place across the country since 2022. Wickremesinghe has been accused of using excessive force to suppress the protests and of violating human rights.

##Handling of economic crisis

Wickremesinghe's government has been criticized for its handling of the economic crisis, which has led to widespread poverty and unemployment. Wickremesinghe has been accused of failing to take adequate measures to address the crisis and of pursuing policies that have exacerbated the problem.

##2023 local government elections

In 2023, Wickremesinghe's government faced a major setback in the local government elections, which were won by the opposition. The incident was seen as a major blow to Wickremesinghe's presidency and led to widespread criticism of his leadership.

##2024 presidential election

In 2024, Wickremesinghe will face a presidential election, which is expected to be a major challenge for his presidency. Wickremesinghe's opponent is likely to be a candidate from the opposition, who will seek to capitalize on the government's unpopularity and the economic crisis.

#Family and personal life

Wickremesinghe is married to Maitree Wickremesinghe, a lawyer and a former judge. The couple has one daughter, Shanika Wickremesinghe, who is a doctor.

Wickremesinghe has received several honors and awards for his service to the country. In 2017, he was awarded the Grand Cross of the Order of the White Rose of Finland.

article:
Killing of Jayland Walker

The killing of Jayland Walker occurred on June 27, 2022, in Akron, Ohio, United States. Walker, a 25-year-old African American man, was shot and killed by eight police officers from the Akron Police Department after a high-speed car chase. The incident sparked widespread protests and calls for police reform, and it remains a significant event in the ongoing national conversation about police brutality and racial justice.

# Background

Jayland Walker was a 25-year-old man from Akron, Ohio. He grew up in the city and attended Buchtel High School. After high school, Walker worked as a DoorDash delivery driver and was an avid skateboarder. Walker's family described him as a kind and gentle person who loved his community and was committed to making a positive impact.

The Akron Police Department has a history of controversy and allegations of police brutality. In 2020, the department was sued by the family of a man who was killed by police during a traffic stop. The lawsuit alleged that the police used excessive force and that the department had a culture of racism and misconduct.

# Incident

On the evening of June 27, 2022, Jayland Walker was driving his car in Akron when he was pulled over by police. According to the police, Walker was stopped for a traffic violation, but Walker's family disputes this account. The police claim that Walker attempted to flee the scene, leading to a high-speed car chase through the city.

The chase ended in a parking lot, where Walker exited his car and began to run. The police claim that Walker posed a threat to the officers, but the exact circumstances of the shooting are disputed. Eight police officers fired a total of 90 shots at Walker, striking him multiple times.

Walker was pronounced dead at the scene. The police department initially released a statement claiming that Walker had been shot after a "confrontation" with officers, but this account has been widely disputed.

# Investigation

The Ohio Bureau of Investigation (BBI) launched an investigation into the shooting, which is ongoing. The BBI has released few details about the investigation, but it is reported to be reviewing body camera footage and interviewing witnesses.

The Akron Police Department has also launched an internal investigation into the shooting. The department has placed the eight officers involved in the shooting on paid administrative leave.

# Body camera footage

Body camera footage of the shooting was released in July 2022. The footage shows the police chasing Walker's car through the city and eventually cornering him in a parking lot. The footage is grainy and difficult to make out, but it appears to show Walker exiting his car and beginning to run.

The footage does not clearly show what happened next, but it appears to show the police firing multiple shots at Walker. The footage is disturbing and has been widely criticized as an example of police brutality.

# Reactions

The killing of Jayland Walker sparked widespread protests and calls for police reform in Akron and across the country. Walker's family and supporters have demanded justice and accountability for the police officers involved in the shooting.

The city of Akron has implemented a number of reforms in response to the shooting, including the creation of a civilian review board to oversee the police department. The city has also increased funding for community programs aimed at reducing violence and improving police-community relations.

## Family reaction to grand jury decision

In January 2023, a grand jury declined to indict the eight police officers involved in the shooting. Walker's family was outraged by the decision, which they described as a " miscarriage of justice".

Walker's mother, Pamela Walker, stated that the family was "heartbroken" by the decision and vowed to continue fighting for justice. Walker's family has filed a lawsuit against the city of Akron and the police department, alleging that the police used excessive force and that the department has a culture of racism and misconduct.

article:
Boys Planet

Boys Planet is a South Korean reality competition television series that premiered on February 2, 2023. The show is produced by Mnet and CJ E&M, and is designed to launch the career of a new K-pop boy group. The series features a unique concept and format, with a focus on competition, training, and evaluation.

Concept and format

Boys Planet is a competition show that brings together 98 trainees from various entertainment agencies to compete for a spot in a new K-pop boy group. The trainees are divided into two groups: "Global" and "K-Group". The Global group consists of trainees from countries outside of Korea, while the K-Group consists of trainees from Korea. The trainees will undergo a series of challenges and evaluations, with the goal of being selected as one of the top 9 members of the new boy group.

article:
2023 The Hundred season

The 2023 season of The Hundred is the third edition of the Hundred, a professional franchise 100-ball cricket tournament in England and Wales. The tournament features eight teams, with a women's and men's competition running concurrently. The season began on July 1, 2023, and is scheduled to conclude on August 27, 2023.

# Teams

The eight teams participating in the 2023 season of The Hundred are:

1. Birmingham Phoenix
2. London Spirit
3. Manchester Originals
4. Northern Superchargers
5. Oval Invincibles
6. Southern Brave
7. Trent Rockets
8. Welsh Fire

Each team represents a different city or region in England and Wales.

# Tournament structure

The 2023 season of The Hundred features a round-robin group stage, followed by a knockout stage. The group stage consists of 32 matches for each competition, with each team playing the other seven teams once. The top three teams in each competition qualify for the knockout stage, which consists of an eliminator and a final.

# Squads

### Women

Each team has a squad of 15 players, with a minimum of two overseas players and a maximum of four. The teams announced their squads in April 2023.

### Men

Each team has a squad of 15 players, with a minimum of two overseas players and a maximum of four. The teams announced their squads in April 2023.

### Replacements

Teams are allowed to make replacements to their squads during the season due to injury or other reasons.

# Format

The 2023 season of The Hundred features a 100-ball innings, with each team facing 100 balls. The game is divided into two innings, with each team batting and bowling once. The team with the higher score at the end of the 100 balls wins the game.

# Broadcasting

The 2023 season of The Hundred is broadcast on Sky Sports and the BBC. Sky Sports has exclusive rights to broadcast the tournament in the UK, while the BBC has the rights to broadcast 10 matches, including the final.

article:
Lahaina, Hawaii

Lahaina is a historic town located on the island of Maui, Hawaii, United States. It is situated on the west coast of Maui, approximately 22 miles northwest of Kahului, the island's largest city. Lahaina is a popular tourist destination known for its rich cultural heritage, stunning natural beauty, and vibrant arts scene. The town has a population of around 12,000 people and is a significant economic hub for the island.

# History

## Name

### Modern name, etymology and pronunciations

The name "Lahaina" is derived from the Hawaiian words "la" meaning "sun" and "haina" meaning "cruel" or "relentless". The name is often translated as "relentless sun" or "cruel sun". The pronunciation of the name is often anglicized as "lah-HY-nah", although the traditional Hawaiian pronunciation is closer to "lah-HAH-nah".

### Ancient names

In ancient times, Lahaina was known by several names, including "Lele" and "Mokuhinia". Lele was the name of a small island located off the coast of Lahaina, which was later connected to the mainland by a canal. Mokuhinia was the name of a nearby island that was once the site of a royal palace.

## Early rulers

Lahaina was an important location for the ancient Hawaiian kingdom, and it was ruled by a series of powerful chiefs and kings. One of the earliest recorded rulers of Lahaina was King Pi'ilani, who ruled Maui in the 16th century. Pi'ilani was a wise and just ruler who established Lahaina as a major center of trade and commerce.

## Western contact

### Kahekili II

The first European to visit Lahaina was the British explorer Captain James Cook, who arrived in 1778. However, it was not until the arrival of King Kahekili II in the late 18th century that Lahaina began to establish significant trade relationships with European powers. Kahekili II was a powerful and ambitious ruler who sought to modernize and strengthen his kingdom through trade and diplomacy.

### Kamehameha I and Kamehameha II

In 1810, King Kamehameha I, also known as Kamehameha the Great, conquered Maui and established Lahaina as his capital. Kamehameha I was a brilliant military strategist and statesman who unified the Hawaiian Islands under one rule. His son, Kamehameha II, succeeded him and continued to rule from Lahaina.

### Christian missionaries

In 1820, the first Christian missionaries arrived in Lahaina, led by Reverend Hiram Bingham. The missionaries had a significant impact on Hawaiian culture, introducing Christianity and Western values to the islands. They also established the first schools and hospitals in Lahaina.

### Whaling

During the 19th century, Lahaina became a major center for the whaling industry. Whalers from around the world came to Lahaina to provision and repair their ships, and the town became a bustling center of commerce and trade.

### Kamehameha III

In 1825, King Kamehameha III ascended to the throne and established a constitutional monarchy in Hawaii. Kamehameha III was a wise and progressive ruler who sought to modernize and strengthen his kingdom through education, economic development, and diplomacy.

### 20th century

In the 20th century, Lahaina continued to grow and develop as a major tourist destination. The town's rich cultural heritage and stunning natural beauty made it a popular destination for visitors from around the world.

## 2023 wildfire

On August 8, 2023, a devastating wildfire swept through Lahaina, burning thousands of acres of land and forcing the evacuation of thousands of people. The fire was sparked by a combination of strong winds and dry conditions, and it quickly spread through the town, destroying homes, businesses, and historic landmarks. The fire was eventually brought under control, but not before it had caused widespread destruction and displacement.

# Geography

## Climate

Lahaina has a tropical savanna climate, with warm temperatures and high humidity levels throughout the year. The average temperature in Lahaina is around 78°F (25°C), with average highs of 85°F (30°C) in the summer and average lows of 70°F (21°C) in the winter. Lahaina receives most of its rainfall during the winter months, with an average annual rainfall of around 20 inches (500 mm).

# Demographics

As of the 2020 census, the population of Lahaina was approximately 12,000 people. The town has a diverse population, with a mix of Native Hawaiians, Caucasians, Asians, and other ethnic groups. The median age in Lahaina is around 40 years old, and the median household income is around $60,000.

# Arts and culture

Lahaina is known for its vibrant arts scene, with numerous galleries, museums, and performance venues. The town is home to the Lahaina Arts Society, which promotes and supports local artists and arts programs. Lahaina is also home to the Maui Theatre, which hosts a variety of performances, including concerts, plays, and musicals.

# Sports

Lahaina is a popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts, with numerous opportunities for surfing, snorkeling, and other water sports. The town is also home to the Lahaina Civic Center, which hosts a variety of sports events, including basketball, volleyball, and soccer.

# Popular culture

Lahaina has been featured in numerous films and television shows, including "The Descendants", "Pirates of the Caribbean", and "Hawaii Five-0". The town's rich cultural heritage and stunning natural beauty make it a popular location for film and television productions.

article:
Tornado Outbreak of March 21–23, 2022

A significant tornado outbreak occurred across the southern United States on March 21–23, 2022, causing widespread damage and loss of life. The outbreak was characterized by a complex series of severe thunderstorms that produced multiple tornadoes, including several intense and long-lived ones. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the meteorological conditions, confirmed tornadoes, non-tornadic effects, preparations, impacts, and aftermath of the outbreak.

# Meteorological Synopsis

## March 21

On March 21, a strong low-pressure system developed over the southern Great Plains, leading to the formation of a dry line that stretched from Texas to Kansas. As the dry line interacted with a warm front, it created a focal point for thunderstorm development. The storms rapidly intensified, producing large hail, damaging winds, and tornadoes. The environment was conducive to supercell formation, with strong wind shear and instability present.

## March 22

On March 22, the low-pressure system moved eastward, bringing the dry line and warm front with it. The storms that developed along the dry line were even more intense than those on March 21, with multiple tornadoes reported across the southern states. The storms were fueled by a strong jet stream and a deepening trough, which provided the necessary lift and instability for sustained supercell activity.

## March 23

On March 23, the low-pressure system continued to move eastward, bringing the severe weather threat to the eastern United States. Although the storms were not as intense as those on March 22, they still produced several tornadoes, particularly in the Carolinas and Georgia. The environment was still conducive to supercell formation, with strong wind shear and instability present.

# Confirmed Tornadoes

## March 21 Event

A total of 15 tornadoes were reported on March 21, with the majority occurring in Texas and Oklahoma. The strongest tornado was an EF3 that occurred in Grayson County, Texas, causing significant damage and injuring several people.

## March 22 Event

A total of 30 tornadoes were reported on March 22, with the majority occurring in Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama. The strongest tornado was an EF4 that occurred in Gretna, Louisiana, causing catastrophic damage and loss of life.

## March 23 Event

A total of 10 tornadoes were reported on March 23, with the majority occurring in the Carolinas and Georgia. The strongest tornado was an EF2 that occurred in Spartanburg County, South Carolina, causing significant damage and injuring several people.

## Gretna–Arabi–New Orleans East, Louisiana

One of the most significant tornadoes of the outbreak occurred in Gretna, Louisiana, where an EF4 tornado caused catastrophic damage and loss of life. The tornado touched down in Gretna at approximately 7:30 pm local time and moved northeastward through Arabi and New Orleans East, causing widespread destruction. The tornado was on the ground for approximately 10 miles and reached winds of up to 170 mph. Several people were killed, and many more were injured in the tornado.

# Non-Tornadic Effects

In addition to the tornadoes, the severe thunderstorms produced large hail, damaging winds, and heavy rainfall. Several reports of hail exceeding 2 inches in diameter were received, and winds gusting up to 80 mph were reported in several areas. The heavy rainfall caused flash flooding in several areas, particularly in Louisiana and Mississippi.

# Preparations and Impacts

The National Weather Service issued several tornado watches and warnings throughout the outbreak, providing critical warnings to those in the affected areas. Emergency management officials and first responders were on high alert, with many shelters and emergency operations centers activated. The outbreak caused significant disruptions to daily life, with several schools and businesses closed due to the severe weather.

# Aftermath

The aftermath of the outbreak saw a massive response and recovery effort, with emergency management officials, first responders, and volunteers working tirelessly to provide aid to those affected. The American Red Cross and other relief organizations provided shelter, food, and emotional support to those in need. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) declared several counties disaster areas, providing federal funding for recovery efforts.

2022 Women's Cricket World Cup

The 2022 Women's Cricket World Cup was the 12th edition of the Women's Cricket World Cup, the premier international women's cricket tournament. It was held in New Zealand from 4 March to 3 April 2022. The tournament featured eight teams, with the top four teams from the 2017 Women's Cricket World Cup qualifying automatically, and the remaining four teams qualifying through a qualification tournament.

#Qualification

The qualification process for the 2022 Women's Cricket World Cup involved a combination of automatic qualification and a qualification tournament. The top four teams from the 2017 Women's Cricket World Cup – England, India, Australia, and South Africa – qualified automatically. The remaining four teams were determined through a qualification tournament, which was held in Zimbabwe in November 2021. The qualification tournament featured 10 teams, with the top three teams qualifying for the World Cup. Bangladesh, Pakistan, and the West Indies ultimately qualified for the tournament.

#Venues

The 2022 Women's Cricket World Cup was held across six venues in New Zealand. The venues were:

* Bay Oval, Mount Maunganui
* Seddon Park, Hamilton
* Basin Reserve, Wellington
* University Oval, Dunedin
* Hagley Oval, Christchurch
* McLean Park, Napier

#Squads

#Matches

The 2022 Women's Cricket World Cup consisted of 31 matches, including 21 group stage matches, four warm-up matches, two semi-finals, and the final.

##Warm-up matches

The warm-up matches were played from 27 February to 1 March 2022. The matches were:

The group stage was played from 4 March to 3 April 2022. The teams were divided into a single group, with each team playing the other teams once. The top four teams from the group stage advanced to the semi-finals.

Piolets d'Or

The Piolets d'Or, also known as the Golden Ice Axes, is an annual mountaineering award that recognizes outstanding achievements in the field of alpinism. The award is considered one of the most prestigious honors in the mountaineering community, and it is bestowed upon climbers who have demonstrated exceptional skill, creativity, and commitment to the sport.

History
--------

The Piolets d'Or was first awarded in 1992, and it was created by the French mountaineering magazine, Montagne. The award was established to recognize and celebrate the achievements of climbers who were pushing the boundaries of what was possible in the mountains. Since its inception, the Piolets d'Or has become an annual tradition, with a new group of winners selected each year.

Multiple Winners
----------------

Some climbers have been fortunate enough to win the Piolets d'Or multiple times. These individuals have demonstrated a consistent level of excellence and innovation in their climbing careers, and they have made significant contributions to the sport of alpinism. Multiple winners of the Piolets d'Or include Reinhold Messner, Ueli Steck, and Lynn Hill, among others.

Criteria
--------

The Piolets d'Or is awarded to climbers who have demonstrated exceptional achievement in the field of alpinism. The selection criteria for the award include the difficulty and novelty of the route, the style and commitment of the ascent, and the overall impact of the climb on the sport of mountaineering. A committee of experienced climbers and mountaineering experts selects the winners each year, based on nominations submitted by the climbing community.

The Piolets d'Or has been widely recognized and respected within the mountaineering community. The award is seen as a pinnacle of achievement, and it is often referred to as the "Oscar" of mountaineering awards. However, the Piolets d'Or has not been without controversy over the years.
